reviewText:
Nobody really knows why this game is good. It's written down on a scroll somewhere. It's a platformer in an ocean of platformers. It's sweet and pretty, it's enough and not too much, it's easy on Normal and sometimes annoying on Normal, cos who enjoys falling to their death repeatedly? But that's the genre.

Get into the swing of things using Thief; mow down skeletons using a bow with up to three arrows in one shot. If she's dead for some reason, choose the knight to mow down even more skeletons. If these classes fail, use the Wizard to get to the next checkpoint. You can even fly Aladdin-style using two conjured planks on top of one another, once you turn on levitation. Leviosaaa, baby!

I haven't tried co-op  and I've yet to play the game on Hard mode, but I'm 4 achievements shy of 100%, so I felt comfortable enough to share my thoughts. Finland has some great developers, so I feel good about supporting them. I rate this game Ihan mahtava

reviewText:
Trine is a puzzle platformer with some action thrown in there. You have three characters that you can switch between on the fly, similar to the old Lost Vikings game. You first have the most useful class, the Thief that can use a grappling hook to wooden ledges, a bow, and a flaming bow to light torches. Then you have the wizard that can magically make boxes by clicking or holding the right trigger and draw a box. You can also draw platforms and click and drag specific things to move them or get them out of your way. You can use your boxes and platforms to crush enemies. These first two classes are a lot of fun and have a lot of depth, but then we get to the third class / character, the warrior. He is just your straight up sword swinger, effective melee character.... with a shield that seems pretty useless.

The game is very beautiful, bright and vibrant. It is also very physics based and the physics feel nice. There are nice visuals with diverse settings and instead of cut scenes, the game just uses narrations as you play, which I greatly prefer. Since it is so visually beautiful, it can be a beast on lesser video cards, even at the lowest setting. Your platforms and boxes crush enemies, objects can be thrown into enemies or through destructible walls, the grappling hook lets you swing, and you can wrap hanging spike traps around platforms so they don't fall. I seemed to get the most fun out of unintentional things, such as teeter tauter platforms combine with Ferris wheel like platforms coupled with skeleton warriors jumping and sliding around to fill the room. The platforming dynamic of moving physics based platforming was a lot of fun.

The controls are very simple, and a controller is highly recommended. You have a jump button, a change weapon button, a trigger for drawing boxes or a grappling hook, two shift character buttons, the left stick controls the character, the right stick is like an aim for the bow, to draw platforms and to aim your shield (which is useless when you can easily dodge attacks). You can aim the bow and the longer you aim it, the further the arrow goes. If you don't like switching between characters, you can also play with a friend, but it is sad there is no online co-op.

Each character has their own health and mana bar, but the mana never really seems to run out with enemies constantly dropping potions. If one character dies, they're dead until you reach a checkpoint, even previous checkpoints. If all three characters die, then you simply restart at the last checkpoint. Its a forgiving system, which I'm happy about.

As you progress through the game, you'll level up to get your choice of skill upgrades. You'll also find new tricks and skills.

The enemies seem competent and dangerous enough. The basic enemy is the skeleton that comes in four flavors, standard, shielded, archer and pyro. They will jump over pits, climb, fall and do everything to get to you (except archers that stand and shoot). The enemy AI seems good enough so every situation can be different  There are also spiders and bats, but for the most part, that's it.

It is a quick game, about 4 - 6 hours, but still a fun play through (not as addictively fun as Guacamelee). There is some replay value here with collecting stuff from each level and no playthrough feels exactly the same due to the physics and AI. It was a good design choice to have collectables stay collected when you enter each level so you don't waste time getting what you already had.

If you can get it cheaper than $10, go for it. If you're not into puzzles, avoid it, because the combat is pretty shallow.

reviewText: Three's companyTrine is great fun in single-player and it's worth experimenting with the three-player co-op even if the game works best as a solo experience. Players are given a set of tools (three characters with unique abilities) and are presented with problems that can be solved in several ways, resulting in an adventure that feels wide open despite being relegated to a mere two dimensions. The beautiful visuals and sound bring this world to life and there is something new to discover around every corner. A lack of enemy variety, disappointing conclusion, and the wonky multiplayer keep Trine from greatness, but this is still a highly recommended puzzle platformer.

reviewText:
I think we should have more of these games nowadays. Trine simply looks stunning! It successfully captures the atmosphere of a medieval fantasy world.

To make it interesting we have 3 protagonists - a knight, a rogue and a wizard - but we can only use one at a time. And no, the wizard cannot conjure up lightning and summon creatures or throw fireballs at the approaching enemies. Amadeus can only create boxes, planks or triangles - objects with which you can proceed further ahead on each level.

And this is where Trine shines: There are many puzzles and you need to think and find the solution. Occasionally, you can progress fast but on your way you notice you have left some collectibles behind. So, while completing the game does not necessarily take long you are apt to spend hours with the game just to make a 100% progress on each stage.

Frozenbyte did a wonderful job when releasing this gem back in 2009. Instead of picking this one you should look for the complete edition which has its sequel, the DLC for the 2nd episode and the soundtrack included. Here in Hungary the retail version of the same bundle costs around 5 EUR and you can activate all the contents via Steam.

You cannot go wrong with this one and as Trine is regularly discounted you can easily find it for a suitable price. Just make sure to grab it with a friend as the sequel includes co-op mode!

reviewText:
My thoughts on Trine:

Trine is a beautifully designed 2D action-jumping-fighting-puzzle solving indie game. You get to play three differennt characters at once - a knight, a thief and a wizard. While obviously only controlling one of them at a time, you can switch between those three at any time, using their individual strenghts and abilities to make it to the other side of the map.
As the knight, you're armed with shield and sword and are capable of lifting heavy objects and throw them at your enemies. The shield can be used to block any incoming attack, while the sword is the perfect weapon to deal with the growing numbers of skeletons, bats, and other enemies that you'll encounter.
The thief is armed with a bow and thus able to fight enemies from afar (duh), and can shoot a rope on wooden objects to swing across pits, pull herself out of them in case you still manage to fall and perform cool looking jumps.
As the wizard, you can summon cubes or planks to make yourself an easy way across pits, build stairs to get over high cliffs or drop them on your enemies.

Each ability and spell can be upgraded throughout the game, like letting you shoot several arrows at once, create more cubes to stack on each other or make your sword even deadlier. There are hundrets of casks granting you exp or mana hidden across the game and finding (and reaching!) them all is no easy task!

The graphics are among the best I've seen on a 2D game, only behind this games successor Trine 2. A special praise goes to the awesome person who created this beautiful soundtrack, the music fits this game just perfectly.

I personally didn't like all of the jumping parts that much, just because I'm usually not a big fan of jumping games (and suck at it too), and died several times over. I know I'm criticising a jumping game for its jumping parts, so someone who's into that kind of stuff will have a really good and challenging time with this game. For people like myself, it's still enjoyable, and swining around with the thief is fun, but after a while it can get boring. There could be more different enemies too, since in like the first three chapters or so all you fight are skeletons and bats.

Lots of good things to be said and a few bad too, still I'd recommend anyone to buy this game, especially if it's on sale for like € 1,- or so.

reviewText:
A beautiful blend of action, platforming, and puzzling Trine manages to offer lots of fun and even some challenge. There are also some RPG elements through level ups, skills, and hidden equipment. I will admit, the story wasn't very gripping and my friends and I would often just skip it, but the gameplay is top notch.

Armed with a bow, the thief is the most agile of the three and you can use her grappling hook to traverse the environment. The knight is the traditional melee character and comes with a shield, sword, and a hammer. Probably the best character though, is the wizard. He can create boxes, planks and floating platforms, and he can also move them around. If that doesn't sound exciting, wait until your slinging boxes at all your enemies or throwing planks on your friends to make them fall into pits.

When you aren't busy knocking each other off of cliffs or into fire or spikes, you will find that Trine is an extremely well made co-op game. Everyone character and player really has to work together to get through the game, and everyone fills a role. The thief's grappling hook is perfect for those hard to reach places and she is often the one retrieving experience potions, though she can hardly do it alone and the wizards platforms help immensely. The wizard is arguably the leader of the team because he is able to carry everyone on platforms, disable traps by obstructing them, and he can handles enemies fairly well with his objects. Admittedly, the knight seems to have the short end of the deal as he really only shines in combat; he can throw boxes and break walls, but there are very few cases outside of combat where he is absolutely necessary.

Trine was the only local co-op game me and my friends would play for quite a while, it was just too good to put down. Now with the automatic update to Enchanted Edition, this game just got better. This game goes on sale often, and I buy it for friends whenever I can because this is a well made game and this is great developer. They worked tirelessly to completely update a 5 year old game that probably didn't rake in as much other less deserving games, and when they finished they just included it for every owner for free.

You might find find a better action platformer, or a better puzzle platformer, but you probably won't find a game that blends the two together well and offers a terrific co-op experience.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Taking place in a ruined and forsake-able kingdom this enjoyable environmental/physics  side-scroller/platformer sees the player take control of three characters simultaneously (a wizard, a knight and a rogue) in order to defeat the undead that have risen to take advantage of the instability that has resulted due to the death of the kingdoms beloved king - plunging the land into chaos.

With the ability to switch between each character on the fly the player must make use of each characters specific skill set (grapple hook for the rouge, strength and shield for the knight and magical conjuring abilities for the mage) to solve the myriad of environmental and physics based puzzles littered throughout the gaming world. With lush and crisp visuals and a charming score Trine easily wins over hearts. Whilst there is nothing particularly difficult about any of the puzzles encountered during the play-through many of them are fun and engaging to solve.

It's such a pity that its all over just before it begins and with only a local drop in/drop out co-op option. I would have liked nothing more than to have a friend from Steam join along with me for this short and often sumptuous ride but alas it is not possible. Frozenbyte have created a wonderful little digital title here that is well worth picking up for puzzle, sidescroller and platform enthusiasts alike.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
By this point you're perhaps already aware that Trine is a very visually stunning game, with some great artwork & lighting yet behind all of that lies a really challenging and fun platform puzzle game.

The level designs are fairly basic to begin with an help introduce you to the 3 characters and their abilities without over complicating things. You have a Wizard (who can build blocks and platforms), a Thief who can swing and climb and a Warrior who can fight.
You can only use one character at a time, but the game lets you switch between them easily enough so it's not hard to link abilities together. So, for example you could build a platform with the Wizard to setup an easy jump and climb with The Thief. It's that level of combination and thinking that makes Trine a fun game to play. It also helps that the designers have done a good job of scaling the difficulty at just about the right pace to keep the game challenging, but never boring or frustrating.
The native 360 Controller support is a welcome feature too, and makes gameplay slightly more friendly.

Further more the developers have kindly updated Trine with the engine from Trine 2, which is why it's now referred to as the 'Enchanted Edition'. The real bonus here is if you already owned Trine, it was updated free of charge.

The only real negative could be the slightly wonky fighting mechanics, but that's none issue as the game isn't about the fighting or enemies.

In short, Trine is a fun, well presented Platform Puzzle game that offers a good combination of problem solving, exploring and physic manipulation. Well worth a play.

One of my favorite coop games ever but suffers from the fact that it is local coop only (something that Trine 2 ended up getting). A good selection of achievements with some really challenging stuff in there including a no-death run on the last level of the game on very hard. That took me a lot of blood, sweat and tears.

Time to 100%: 13-15 hours

reviewText:
Fantasy Threesome - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Platformers are a dime a dozen. They're everywhere. The market has been saturated since the NES days, back when sides weren't meant to be scrolled. But they made that jump. And once the floodgates were open and the money was there, the industry got hit. In this day and age, it takes a lot for a platformer to stand out from the crowd. Especially when you consider that it's the genre Nintendo almost monopolizes, with the exception of smaller franchises and indies.


Super Mario is a powerhouse. And all of his Nintendo cronies run the platformer business. But that doesn't mean a billion smaller upstarts can't nibble away at the glory of a AAA publisher, putting out their own innovative or gorgeously styled games. Some might even outshine Nintendo at their own game.


Trine is one of those games, managing to nail smart level design and chaotic multiplayer in a way Nintendo always tries to. Originally for PC and PS3 and later remasted as Trine: Enchanted Edition for PC, PS4, and Wii U.


Trine is a game about boxes. Boxes and skeletons.


A knight, a wizard, and a thief walk into a tomb. You've probably heard this one. They find a treasure. A couple hundred skeletons and boxes later, they all live happily ever after.


That's the whole game.


A clever physics-based puzzle platformer, Trine is simply gorgeous and a pleasure to play. Utilizing an interesting three-character system, you'll have to use the powers of different characters to advance through different portions of long, puzzle-filled levels. An agile thief, a powerful knight, and a wizard. He's not really powerful or agile. But he's a ♥♥♥♥ing wizard.


Their different abilities are the key to making it through the game's tricky puzzles. And what makes the game so fascinating is the amount of thought put into making each level friendly toward each character. The thief uses a grappling hook to reach far off places, while the wizard can generate platforms to help reach the. The knight can't really do either, but he's by far the sturdiest of the trio and has the easiest time dispatching enemies. It's an interesting power dynamic.


When playing by yourself, Trine is a pretty good platformer. You'll be mildly challenged. You'll need to figure out the best hero for each obstacle, and the proper series of powers to use to solve each. It's pretty easy, honestly. You just figure it out, switch to that character and go. But Trine's multiplayer mode is by far where the most potential is. Because suddenly, you can't just switch to the character you need. That character is somewhere else. And maybe that character isn't doing what you're saying. Maybe they have their own ideas on how to solve things.


Trine's multiplayer is complimented by the level design, encouraging not just progression by creative progression. There's multiple solutions to each puzzle, and there's usually multiple paths. It all comes down to how competent your platforming and wizarding are.


Those are really the only two skills needed for the game. Though it is fun, Trine does tend to stick to the same couple puzzles over and over. Variations on a theme, or making things slightly more complicated or dangerous. But never quite pushing the limits of what it's capable of. And I suppose it's better off that way, seeing as how some of these basic physics puzzles are hard enough to solve with an incompetent party of three.


At the very least, Trine is gorgeous. It's impossible to deny that. The Enchanted Edition does offer some upgraded looks, but the original is still as beautiful today as itgreat was when it first launched. Complimented by a great soundtrack, Trine does a perfect job of really building and selling its world. I'm not even particularly a fan of the generic fantasy setting, but Trine pulls it off impeccably.


Out of the millions of platformers out there, this one is pretty good. It's interesting, has a nice multiplayer gimmick. Some boxes, skeletons. Skeletons are great, everyone loves skeletons.


Sometimes you just need to unwind with some boxes and skeletons, you know? And this is the perfect game for those moments.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
I have already reviewed Trine2, after the enchanted update was released I don't know how much different this review will be from my first review of Trine2. (I'll refrain from the temptation of copy pasting my old review, but definitely check out my trine2 review! )
Trine Enchanted Edition is a 2D fantasy adventure RPG, where you can choose between three different characters whom all have different play styles. You can get through most of the levels and puzzles simply by playing as one character, or make it easier on yourself and switch characters.
https://youtu.be/z17ZMGjKJrI
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  I don't want to give away too much about the story, because the story is what makes this game so great. Whenever I play this game I feel like I'm listening to a bed time story being red to me by my grandfather. It has a magical attraction too it, many times it's very over-the-top just like real fairy tales, but it's that approach that just makes a game like Trine, shine (rhyme intended).
You play as Zoya the thief, Amadeus the wizard, and Pontius the stout errr knight; each one has a unique game play style, but I'll explain more about that later, these three hero's are joined together by the trine, and must save the kingdom!

Game Play: As has been hinted above, you play as three characters: Zoya, Amadeus, and Pontious. Firstly, Zoya (thief) is the most agile character, you shoot arrows, grapple hook and swing your way around the game. Amadeus (wizard), being a wizard can conjure up boxes that can be dropped on enemies, or used to help get to high hard-to-reach-locations. reviewText:
This is a very original game. It has a platform gameplay that we all know but with things I had never seen in any game of this type.

The gameplay It's primarily based on puzzles, how it works with physics is really interesting and innovative for games of this type, it is a challenging game and managed to leave me very frustrated at times (like some oldschool games could). I found very cool and unique the way you control 3 characters with different characteristics, but known to all RPG players, and using them to overcome obstacles, really innovative. The visual graphics are very well done and beautiful for a 2D game and the sound is also relaxing and enjoyable to listen when playing.

Just missed a greater variety of enemies and more challenging ones. Anyway, I recommend!

8/10

reviewText:
OverviewTrine is the first iteration of the trilogy which bears the same name. It is a 2.5D action puzzle sidescroller with a focus on visual art and environmental atmosphere. The game features three characters - a wizard, a thief and a warrior - which have been magically bound together, and the player can switch between the three in an attempt to fight spawning skeletons and conjure objects to help getting to hard to reach areas of the map. The puzzles are minimal, so don't expect a brain-teaser, however the challenge to overcome obstacles and areas where good timing and reflexes are mandatory keep the game fun, especially in Co-Op mode.

The Pros Beautiful Visuals - What makes this game really stand out from most side scrollers and platformers in general is the art style. The forced perspective turns this game into a 2.5D effectively, however the surrounding environments are actual 3D objects, and they are simply beautiful. Each level has its own assets, and everywhere you go you can see brightly colored backgrounds with beautiful, atmospheric lightning which at first glance will take away the focus from the gameplay just to admire it. The low resources needed to run this game also ensures a glorious 1080p60fps experience to accompany the already fancy graphics.

Humorous Characters - Even though the game is not focused on its lore and backstory, the three characters have a     personality, and a funny one at that. Through the levels, you can hear them exchange some dialogue that will make you grin at least. Makes the gameplay seem much less fake.

Replayability - The levels feature hidden treasure chests and XP bottles as well as a determined number of monsters you need to kill in order to fully complete it. It makes the player want to return to these levels and search for hidden areas. While at times you will struggle to find that one last missing XP bottle and get frustrated, it's still fun to go through the levels again, nonetheless.

Skills and Inventory - As you progress through the story and gather XP and find hidden treasure chests, you will level up your characters and improve their abilities, as well as find items that you can distribute as you wish among the three protagonists to boost their stats. Adds a certain degree of strategy as you build your characters and makes spending some extra time in uncovering those secret areas worth-while.

Co-Op Mode - You can play this game in co-op with up to two other friends, each controlling one character or anyone can play with anything. Makes the game both more fun and more easy(depending on your friends).
The Cons Not Challenging Enough - the game, even on hard, is pretty easy to beat. If you are careful, even the Hardcore mode isn't too much of a challenge. Do not mistake this with the game being un-fun. It just doesn't represent a hard enough gameplay for those adventurous gamers.

Unbalanced Characters - The thief, with multi-arrow shots and extreme maneuverability from the grappling hook is blatantly overpowered, and combined with the mage's Floating Platform" skill makes it incredibly easy to just swing through the levels easily. The warrior is the most useless of all
date: except for very little occasions.\n\nShort Playthrough - Starting a new game as an experienced player and going through it again at a slow pace will take you about five hours. While a Co-Op wizard Floating-Platform + Thief Grapple style of soaring through the levels
recommended: ignoring XP and enemies could get you somewhere around two hours to complete. There are 17 levels in total
hoursPlayed: along with a boss fight that is more or less... missing. The boss level is just a "Climb to the top of the tower before the lava reaches you" minigame
voteText: albeit a bit hard and frustrating.\nConclusionThis game is very fun while it lasts and the Co-Op revives it at times. I recommend this to platformer and action puzzle fans. Steam Achievements

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Trine Enchanted Edition
Original Release: 2009
Genre Tags: Platformer; Adventure; Puzzle; Coop; Beautiful Artwork
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 12-30 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers; Multiplayer gamers
REVIEWTrine is a light game that is easy to digest but offers gripping visuals, a mystical atmosphere, and enticing gameplay.  All of the features of the game are simple in design but intricate in execution.  The gameplay, aesthetics, and narrative all come together to create a whimsical and charming adventure. I highly recommend this for all gamers to consider; and for fans of the genre it is a sure bet.

By far the best aspects of the game are the stunning visuals and alluring atmospheric presentation of the setting. Each and every environment you explore is diverse, captivating, and charming. The ambiance really captures the mystical aura of the game perfectly. Trine easily has one of the most immersive 2D gameworlds I have encountered in video games.

The gameplay is light and quick to grasp. Anyone should be able to dive right in, regardless of ability level. But various difficulty levels and a hardcore" mode ensure that skilled players can still find a challenge. And whether you are playing on “easy” or “hardcore
date: ” the gameplay is entertaining. Mixing elements of platforming
hoursPlayed: and puzzle solving with the unique identity of the game establishes an experience that is simultaneously familiar and novel— and irrefutably fun.\n\nThe story is whimsical and fantastic; and the characters are pleasant and endearing. This synergizes well with the aforementioned atmosphere to establish an amusing fantasy experience. But it also remains light and relaxed
voteText: and never takes itself too seriously.  So even casual fans of fantasy will enjoy the narrative.\n\nTrine is definitely a worthy pick-up. No matter what your standard preferences are

votesHelpful: as the unique gameplay is a joy to experience with friends.\n\nFollow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!"

reviewText:
This is a long review so if you just want a summary of why I recommend Trine skip to Results and read from there.

Frozenbyte creates an epic story with the brilliant game Trine. Trine offers a side-scroller hack ‘n slash platformer game that combines puzzles with action packed adventures.

Story:
In a magical far away land the world is slowly falling apart as corruption spreads through the kingdom. Yet who will save the kingdom, but three mismatched fools who found themselves drawn to an artifact of power. A lustful wizard Amadeus, a greedy thief Zoya, and a gluttonous knight Pontius all become bound by the Trine. The Trine takes the heroes essences and combines them into one individual. In order to free themselves from the Trines bindings they must complete the quest and bring peace back to the land.

Campaign:
The campaign offers a great tutorial which starts off as you playing each of the characters as they find their way to the Trine. After you have got each character to the Trine the campaign truly begins. There are fifteen levels: Astral Academy, Academy Hallways, Wolvecote Catacombs, Dragon Graveyard, Crystal Caverns, Crypt of the Damned, Forsaken Dungeons, Throne of the Lost King, Fangle Forest, Shadowthorn Thicket, Ruins of the Perished, Heartland Mines, Branblestoke Village, Iron Forge, and Tower of Sarek. Each level includes puzzles, secrets, and numerous enemies. Some of the levels are incredibly long, although all the of levels have checkpoints spread throughout so even if you die you will only be set back a small bit. The campaign offers a lot of amazing features, but the best part is that how you complete the puzzles is up to you.

Gameplay:
The Trine allows you to play as three characters, but you can only operate one of them at a time; the Trine operates as a way to switch your characters. Amadeus, the Wizard, uses spells to conjure platforms and boxes which you can use to build structures, as weapons, or even as a shield. Zoya, the Thief, has a bow and a grappling hook giving her the benefit of range and agility. Pontius, the Knight, has a shield and sword which makes him a formidable tank. The levels are filled with puzzles and mysteries, but unlike most other puzzle games Trine allows you to choose how you complete the puzzle. Use Amadeus to activate switches, or maybe stand on it with Zoya and grappling hook before the door shuts. How you solve the puzzles and defeat the many foes ahead is up to you. I played the game and essentially never used Pontius, not that he is bad, but I preferred to play as Zoya and Amadeus.

Results:
If you love hack ‘n slash puzzle games then this is the adventure you have been awaiting. Trine is a fantastic game at an incredibly reasonable price. If you can get Trine on sale, even if the sale is only 10% off, you are getting one incredible deal. Trine offers character variation, brilliant dialogue, a wonderful ambience, a fantastic story, and gameplay that is almost impossible to find elsewhere. By combining Hack ‘n Slash, Plat former, Puzzle, and RPG Trine offers something that everyone would love. I would entirely recommend Trine and every second you don’t have it is just another second you will regret once you’ve got it.

Pros:
+Fantastic story, dialogue and storybook cut scenes.
+Amazing level design, puzzles and secrets.
+Awesome level up system that allows you to customize your heroes and equip them with items.
+Great character depth, variation, and combination.
+Beautiful ambience, music and scenery.

Cons:
-Getting each of the characters to full ability essentially requires 100% completion.
-In rare instances I have had a glitch where my characters fell out of the map (this was not too much a problem as I would just switch to another character).

reviewText:
This franchise is my favorite side scroller franchise I have yet played. Now, let it be know that I am not an established or seasoned gamer. However, I am a huge fantasy lover and so for me this game is a win on a level that transends simply gameplay. Now to start, the gameplay is excellent. Each of the three characters are perfect manifestations of the stereotypical types of classic fantasy. This game is an excellent romp of fantasy. The archery, magic, swinging, melee, and just about every other feature of the three characters is well thought out and impressively executed. The narrative is perfectly balanced between not actually being too imporant that it takes itself too seriously, but also adding an excellent layer of culture to the game world. The soundtrack as well is quite exceptional and really adds to the atmosphere.

Though at the end of the day it just comes to the fact the gameplay is just undeniably solid.

End.

reviewText: Trine is a 2D action puzzle platformer. You take control of 3 different characters all with different abilities on your way to take down your enemies, avoid hazardous traps and collect treasures. The visuals are beautiful with vivid colours and the animations are satisfying. There is nothing special about it's story, but it is enough to keep you going with a nice sense of storytelling. The soundtrack on the other hand is gorgeous with various orchestral tracks arranged by Ari Pulkkinen and it really fits the game.\n\nWith it's visuals, soundtrack and gameplay combined, Trine offers around 9 hours of pure fun and even more for the completionists. It's a must buy for every action puzzle platformer lover over there!

reviewText:
This is a long review so if you just want a summary of why I recommend Trine skip to Results and read from there.

Frozenbyte creates an epic story with the brilliant game Trine. Trine offers a side-scroller hack ‘n slash platformer game that combines puzzles with action packed adventures.

Story:
In a magical far away land the world is slowly falling apart as corruption spreads through the kingdom. Yet who will save the kingdom, but three mismatched fools who found themselves drawn to an artifact of power. A lustful wizard Amadeus, a greedy thief Zoya, and a gluttonous knight Pontius all become bound by the Trine. The Trine takes the heroes essences and combines them into one individual. In order to free themselves from the Trines bindings they must complete the quest and bring peace back to the land.

Campaign:
The campaign offers a great tutorial which starts off as you playing each of the characters as they find their way to the Trine. After you have got each character to the Trine the campaign truly begins. There are fifteen levels: Astral Academy, Academy Hallways, Wolvecote Catacombs, Dragon Graveyard, Crystal Caverns, Crypt of the Damned, Forsaken Dungeons, Throne of the Lost King, Fangle Forest, Shadowthorn Thicket, Ruins of the Perished, Heartland Mines, Branblestoke Village, Iron Forge, and Tower of Sarek. Each level includes puzzles, secrets, and numerous enemies. Some of the levels are incredibly long, although all the of levels have checkpoints spread throughout so even if you die you will only be set back a small bit. The campaign offers a lot of amazing features, but the best part is that how you complete the puzzles is up to you.

Gameplay:
The Trine allows you to play as three characters, but you can only operate one of them at a time; the Trine operates as a way to switch your characters. Amadeus, the Wizard, uses spells to conjure platforms and boxes which you can use to build structures, as weapons, or even as a shield. Zoya, the Thief, has a bow and a grappling hook giving her the benefit of range and agility. Pontius, the Knight, has a shield and sword which makes him a formidable tank. The levels are filled with puzzles and mysteries, but unlike most other puzzle games Trine allows you to choose how you complete the puzzle. Use Amadeus to activate switches, or maybe stand on it with Zoya and grappling hook before the door shuts. How you solve the puzzles and defeat the many foes ahead is up to you. I played the game and essentially never used Pontius, not that he is bad, but I preferred to play as Zoya and Amadeus.

Results:
If you love hack ‘n slash puzzle games then this is the adventure you have been awaiting. Trine is a fantastic game at an incredibly reasonable price. If you can get Trine on sale, even if the sale is only 10% off, you are getting one incredible deal. Trine offers character variation, brilliant dialogue, a wonderful ambience, a fantastic story, and gameplay that is almost impossible to find elsewhere. By combining Hack ‘n Slash, Plat former, Puzzle, and RPG Trine offers something that everyone would love. I would entirely recommend Trine and every second you don’t have it is just another second you will regret once you’ve got it.

Pros:
+Fantastic story, dialogue and storybook cut scenes.
+Amazing level design, puzzles and secrets.
+Awesome level up system that allows you to customize your heroes and equip them with items.
+Great character depth, variation, and combination.
+Beautiful ambience, music and scenery.

Cons:
-Getting each of the characters to full ability essentially requires 100% completion.
-In rare instances I have had a glitch where my characters fell out of the map (this was not too much a problem as I would just switch to another character).

reviewText:
Personally I really can't recommend this game enough.

The story, the setting, the graphics, the artdesign, the music, the sound effects, the voiceacting (even in german) and the level design are perfectly blended into a package of pure fun and excitement.

Because you have three characters for play at once there are nearly always different ways of solving a problem. Sometimes you have to switch rapidly between the charakters to get one particular problem done. Some other time you can choose which way of progress suits you the most.

I think this game is one of the best 2D (ok the graphics are 3D so I assume it's one of those modern called 2.5D" game-enignes) platformers you can get today though I must say I haven't played the second part yet and I hope it will be even better than this part of the series.

There are demos available of both parts of the gage. Go on
recommended: be stunned by the exellence of execution in this title and then buy it. It's worth every penny even more though it's on discount on nearly a regular basis.\n\nThere is only one thing that annoys me a little and that is the impossibility to look up or down. There are a few spots
voteText:
where you simply fall to death and there is no glimpse of a warning. I've played games where at least you can move near the edge and the player character gives a sign wether it's possible to jump down a hole or not. Maybe this would be a nice addition to any future parts of the series. And jesus how I hope they'll do any.

As there are really fair and nearly too much checkpoints throughout the levels this is only a minor flaw and doesn't diffuse gameplay flow too much but it could have been solved nicer the way I described above ... nonetheless ...

... if you are a fan of 2D action platformers with puzzle elements you simply HAVE to buy this game.

You most likely won't regret it !!!"

reviewText: What can I say about Trine? It's pretty good. This is how character switching should be done (I'm looking at you CreaVures!). In Trine you play as three separate characters who are magically bound together, due to the three touching some hokey magical item that apparently does this, and only one of the characters can be active at once in some sort of multiple personality disorder situation where your other personalities can bring weapons along with them. Makes sense? No? Well it doesn't have to because the gameplay is good. Trine doesn't make you go back and walk your other characters through the same level after one has cleared it already because all characters occupy the same space. Good old platforming with skill switching to accomplish certain tasks. That is what Trine offers and it does not fail to disappoint.

reviewText: I have played Trine when it first came out, many years ago, and i was pleasantly surprised by this little gem. Now, after completing Trine 2 this summer, i have decided to play first one in Steam. And, boy, it looks old. Well, looks are still pretty, especially some places like the Iron Forge. But the physics are bad, comparing to the new one. I know it is not fair. But it was harder to control objects and control heroes in this one. Experience collecting achievements are easier in this one, but still there are some hidden in lava or acid or other invisible places bottles, which made me mad sometimes. And skeletons. I wish there were fewer of them. They usually do not pose any threat and you just have to stand and shoot them, one by one, one by one, hordes of skeletons on every level section. You can skip them, if you don't want to collect enemies experience and if you don't want to level up or get the achievements. Yes, so you have to stand and shoot (or smash with the knight). This just creates boredom in this unique game of physics puzzles. So it could be less dumb enemies and more puzzles, or maybe a few smarter enemies. But i'm still recommending this now a classic game of its genre.

reviewText: I love Trine!!! Now usually I'm not into being emo about games, but this one is great. The presentation is beautiful, a nice, colorful fantasy world with detailed graphics that   one just has to like by looking at, acompanied by a score that adds to the magic of this game. Of course there are some small glitches, caused by physics going rogue, though that doesn't happen to often to be annoying (just occasinally every now and then). Controls are straight forward, as is the gameplay. You'll be swingin, conjuring objects, smashing bones (the undead ones :P) and launching arrows in no time. OK, one has to admit that there not many enemy types, but this doesn't kill the fun. Overall, this is a must play!!!

reviewText:
Fairytale graphics in a telling story
This is quite a good game, still very playable in 2014 considering its age (it was first released in 2009). It's not a classic sidescroller-platformer, more like an 2.5D platform game with moderately difficult puzzels incorporating jumping and some nice, quite modern feeling physics.

You play as one of three members of a party (a Wizard, a Knight and a Thief), and the nice touch is that you can switch between these three at any given time. This is often necessary to solve a puzzle or to make further progresss in the game, which means that once a party member is killed, chances are there you have to go back to the last savepoint. Thankfully, these are plenty enough to keep things agreeable - mind you, not quick save in this one. A bit surprisingly, difficulty seems to diminish once the game gets going - after level 5 or so (from the 15). Since by then you have far more abilities and more powelfull weapons, it gets easier to bruise through the levels. That's not a real problem, since each new level presents an different set of colours and atmosphere, but it is somehow surprising.

The department where Trine really shines, is its visuals. Not that there are really fancifull effects, it's just that the atmosphere of the different levels is captured to perfection. There is something fairytale-like about Trine, which is really enthralling and keeps one playing for a while.And since the Enchanted Edition was relased, visuals have even been improved by more than a notch. Alas, the story really is not so entertaining, so after a bunch of levels you could lose intesest. Physics are great and enhanch the puzzels to a considerable effect, since you often have to resort to them.

Still: recommended for those who love a game with real atmosphere and good albeit rather simple game mechanics.

Gameplay: 22/30
Graphics: 15/20
Sound: 7/10 (nothing spectacular here, but the music really is fine)
Stability/patching: 18/20
Long-lasting appeal/replayability: 12/20 (there is local co-op)

Overall: 74/100

reviewText:
Trine is an absolutely incredible game. In this review, I will list the many things I loved about it and the few things I disliked.

Pros:
1) The graphics are absolutely gorgeous. They're extremely colorful  and detailed.
2) The abilities of the characters are well thought out, and you are rewarded for looking for chests.
3) The mechanics of the three characters work very well together. Near the end of the game, I was finding myself subconsciously switching from one character to another.

Cons:
1) The characters would occasionally glitch out, especially while using the Theif's grapple.
2) Enemies were not developed well. Much of the time, a skeleton trying to attack me would begin running and swinging at a wall. Took away from the immersion and flow of gameplay.
3) Bosses were not made well. [SPOILER ALERT] I had to face the same two bosses twice. I defeated the first one, then the second one, then I had to face the first one again, and the second one again. These were the only bosses (excluding the final boss). Also, as I was fighting with them, they glitched out. The second/fourth boss froze during battle and let me kill him.
4) The story of the game was short and undeveloped. I'm still rather confused about the plot of the game. If most games create a story and base the game off the story, it seems like Trine made the game and then wrote the story afterwards. I would've liked more character development/attatchment. As well, the story itself didn't last long. I beat the game in 6.9 hours, which included me gathering nearly every experience bottle and chest in every map.
5) The end of the game was not satisfying whatsoever. [SPOILER ALERT] The final boss isn't a fight. You must climb through a level rapidly, fighting skeletons and destroying objects dropped on you with the boss. In the end, you climb onto a platform with the 3 artifacts, and you win. Then, during a cutscene, the boss" tries to attack the theif
date: and gets crushed in one hit by the Knight's hammer. This wasn't satisfying at all
recommended: the battle was intense enough but the end left me feeling cheated out of something
hoursPlayed: like I still needed to finish the battle.\n\nAll-in-all
voteText: this game would be absolutely astounding if the developers were more thorough. Whether this was due to a low budget
helpfulPercent: time limitations
votesHelpful: or lazy development
votesTotal: the game felt incomplete. I recommend buying this game and playing it if you're looking for some fun. I hope the next two games will be better developed
votesFunny: and if you plan on playing those
commentsCount: I highly suggest playing this first to get even a vague idea of what the story is about."

reviewText:
In a world of games filled with Actions, Colors, and generally noise. Specially in a world itself filled with noise and busyness outside of video games. I think Trine fits beautifuly to fill an abandoned and necessarily needed gap.

It is a simple game, so simple in fact I can even recommend it to the young ones. The puzzles are simple but not lame, the artistic style is incredible, voice acting though scarcley there is well done, sound effects are top notch. It's really hard to believe the effort put into this game despite it's nature. The attention to details is in every corner. Every technical aspect is top notch.I didn't play CO-OP so I can't speak about that though
.
The main thing is, I found it really fun to just play a simple game that let's you relax. Still, not simple enough that it's poorly excuted. This is a game every gamer should play to relax from his/her typical competitive online or dynamic rich single player game. Already have the 2nd installment in my library, and WILL get the 3rd one too.

reviewText:
Trine really is a gem of a game, and goes to show that you don't need a massive budget to produce a piece of art. Best played, with a friend, Trine can also be played alone, and is almost as much fun solo.

Featuring beautiful graphics, tight controls and relaxing, interesting gameplay, Trine sees you (and possibly a friend) take control of three characters, which must be switched between in order to complete levels, as each has their own set of skills. The physics also play their part in the puzzles, which are reasonably easy to get through.

Highly recommended if you like platformers, co-op or are just looking to try something new.

reviewText:
I played through this game before as co-op, before achievements.
Now after opening the game the first time after enchanted edition and gathering all the achievements, here's my view:

Game is awesome. As it was, as it will be.
The atmosphere is amazing. The visuals and bgm just go hand-to-hand so perfect there's no question you'll immerse yourself in this game the moment you open it.

However it's MUCH shorter than I remembered. I 100%'d the game in about 2-3 hours.

Anyways, get it.

reviewText: Trine is a fun physics-based puzzle/platformer featuring 3 main characters, each with unique abilities: the Knight is your typical close combat brawler; the Thief fights at long range with a bow and can utilize a grappling hook; and the Wizard can create and manipulate different types of objects. The characters (which can be swapped at will) each have their own unique way of tackling the levels, which makes for lots of variety in how the game can be played. Gameplay takes place on a 2D plane, but the environments are all rendered (gorgeously, I might add) in full 3D. The story is fairly generic, but the voice acting is decent. Combat is done well and is pretty fun, but unfortunately gets old pretty quickly - you'll be fighting the same few enemies over and over again throughout the whole game. The issue isn't a deal-breaker by any means.. it's just a tad disappointing. All in all, Trine is a really well done game which I fully recommend for 2D platforming fans.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Trine is a great 2D adventure game. The 3-characters mechanics that you can get out of this simple game are amazingly deep, and you will have a lot of fun flying around with the wizard, shooting arrows with the thief, and smashing enemies with the warrior. Voice acting is spot-on, the graphical style is immense... you won't regret it!

reviewText: Cute, charming but incredibly frustrating at times. The visuals are great, the game looks like a fairy tale. Controls are fluid and responsive, although there are a few hiccups at times. The music is charming, but, unfortunately, quite repetitive. The puzzles aren't too hard, but what makes the game frustrating is the uselessness of the Wizard and the waaay to strong enemies. They are too hard to kill, in my opinion. And the worst part of the game is the last level, on which I died many more time than I admit to. Much too hard, and not rewarding at all.\nOverall, the game is worth forking 8 bucks, but if you're not really into puzzles and fairy tales, you'd better wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Trine is absolutely one of the most appealing games I have ever played! From it's gorgeous visuals, fantastic soundtrack, excellent narration, and fluent mechanics, it's no wonder this game was such a success!

Trine focuses on the diversity of it's titular characters, and the level design of it's extremely well built maps. Each character has a unique role in the game, from the Knight, Wizard, and Thief - with each character being compatible with the other in terms of move sets, and combat. The games platforming works exceptionally well, and the puzzles (while not necessarily that difficult), provide enough thought and complexity to some of the maps level design thus creating entertainment and replayability in leaps and bounds!

Now, while the game is incredibly fun playing solo, it should definitely be tackled cooperatively. Amusing antics and crazy combinations will put a smile on your face, and keep you coming back repeatedly! However, Trine doesn't boast online multiplayer"
recommended: it is still an excellent title and definitely deserves a playthrough! In the end
hoursPlayed: Trine is well worth the asking price in terms of content

reviewText: A very polished game, visually and gameplay-wise.  Fun on many levels. reviewText:
Trine is a game everyone should play or try out; from the beautiful AAA worthy art style to great game mechanics, excellent voiceover and engaging storyline, this is the ultimate platformer game experience.
Complementing the already great single player experience is the co-op multiplayer both local and with Trine Enchanted now online as well.
Frozenbyte has really done an exceptional job with this game and have one of the best PC support teams around; be it with troubleshooting small bugs to giving existing owners the Enchanted update for free.

This is one game you should not skip.

Looking forward to playing Trine 2 and future Frozenbyte games.

reviewText: A good platforming/puzzle solving game. You can switch between a thief, mage, or knight at any time to solve different puzzles and fight. The graphics are outstanding, especially for an indie game. Probably the best graphics I've ever seen in a indie game, really high quality professional grade. Tight, responsive controls (I play with a wired xbox 360 controller), good sound, great gameplay, and just a really well made game that is a pleasure to look at and play. It's only downfall is that it is very short (6 hours or so). 8/10

reviewText:
Trine was released in an era when the side-scroller was a lacking appearance on PC. It sports gorgeous backgrounds, funny puzzles (which can be solved, avoided and even completely exploited thanks to the 3 heroes' abilities) and at points witty dialogues, successfuly breaking the rhythm of slaying countless waves of monsters.

The developer, Frozenbyte offers amazing support - Linux works, OS X works, full keyboard + mouse, XInput gamepad (Xbox controller), multiplayer and couch multiplayer (just plug in the controllers, with up to 2 buddies on the couch and hack and slash your way through the campaign). The game also supports stereoscopic 3D - and it's among the few games natively doing it, a true show-off, with its vivid colors and spectacular backgrounds on 3D TVs.

A must have for Big Picture Mode, together with its sequel - Trine 2. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
When I first saw this game, which was on sale, I got stucked in front of my desktop screen: it was somehow... attractive.
I saw its videos and I instantly loved it. -85%, it was very worth. Then, shall we start:
Though I have never played RPG-platforms games like this one I've to say that it's awesome.  The art ist beautiful, the landscapes of the different levels are enjoyable. It's a perfect environment for the game. I've played the italian version so I don't know how are the english voices but the italian ones were pretty good so I guess the english' are as well. It was really the same as being told a story by a storyteller. And the music. OMG. It was so eargasmic. Such a pity it doesn't come along with the Enchaned Edition. Fortunately in Trine 2 it does and it's quite similar from what I listened.
The game is a puzzle-kind that offers exploration to fulfill completely the levels. I'm a perfectionist, so I tried to collect every collectable that existed. In many levels I couldn't, so I'll try them again until I get all the potions and secrets. Some are hard to get and others to find.
Then, I've to say that is rather short, in 7 hours I finished it (the 0.8 h it's due to my play in co-op) and well, the story isn't very immersive but still is beautiful. It's a cliched one and it has no cutscenes. And the final" battle it was somehow dissapointing completing the level was harder than defeating the boss. In fact

reviewText:
Trine turned out to be rather fun. Probably more fun in co-op mode but the game still works fine in single player.

The basic story in Trine is that one night, Zoya the thief, Amadeus the Wizard, and Pontius the knight, touch a magical object known as the trine at the same time, thus disappearing from the Astral Academy. Zoya was there to scavenge for treasures as the Academy had recently been evacuated due to the incoming undead army. Adameus stayed behind to work  on potions, and Pontius had only just arrived, convinced he was supposed to protect the academy. Binded by the trine, the trio work together and adventure through forests, tombs, catacombs, castles, to try and find the artifacts that would break the spell.

As a sidescrolling 3D game it has a remarkable attention to detail. The backgrounds are filled with art pieces and the levels are designed rather well, never being repetitive in style or layout. The enemies are repetitive though, aside from the few bosses. The gameplay consists of using each of the characters special abilities to get past blocks in the path, etc.

Anyway, I really liked it.

9/10

reviewText:
This review is for the game ''Trine'',a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game,developed by the video game company ''Frozenbyte'' and published by Nobilis(wordwide).It was released in July 3,2009 for Microsoft Windows and since then the game has been released for the PlayStation Network,Mac OS X and for Linux as well.Trine uses the Proprietary engine.

Plot
Trine takes place in a magical but destroyed kingdom.After a brief period of peace,the king died without leaving any heir.So the kingdom descented to anarchy.During this political instability an undead army appears and attacks the kingdom destroying everything that's on its path.

After some time three heroes,unkown to each other,reach the Astral Academy,a magical institution,where they touch a magical object,later said to be the Trine,and their souls bind together.After that incident they search for a way to free themselves of that peculiar effect.The trio must eventually undergoe  an adventure searching for three artifacts that once reunited they could be free.Apparently the Trine is the artifact of souls and without it the other two(the artifact of the body and the artifact of the mind) created the undead making them responsible for all the chaos that polutes the kingdom.

After finding them they face a last ultimate challenge where they combine the Trine with the two lost artifacts,unbinding their souls forever.The game ends with the storyteller informing us that the kingdom has been cleansed from the undead and the three proclaiming it as its heroes.

Characters
You take control of Zoya,the thief,Amadeus,the wizard,and Pontius,the knight.Each of them has special abilities.Zoya is the stealthy one of the group and uses her bow and arrow,making her an exceptional marksman.Amadeus uses the power of magic,allowing him to conjur objects(planks,cubes,pyramids) helping the team to overcome obstacles and reach remote areas with great ease.Last but not least Pontius uses his sword,shield and sledgehammer with great force,making him the group's main damage dealer.The player is supposed to combine the group's power together in order to accomplish difficult stunts and unlock the group's true prowess.

Recap
Incredible game,breathtaking graphics,with exceptional yet simple plot.Enjoyed every bit of it and i definetely recommend it.

Edit Friday 4 July 2014
Trines has been updated with extremely good looking visual customizations and now is called Trine the Enchanted edition.You should try it out,everybody can be a Beta participant thanks to Frozenbyte developers.

P.S Support the developers.Frozenbyte thank you for this game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Trine is a game I can't recommend enough.  It's a physics platformer with a rather unique mechanic of 3 playable characters.  They are tied together by magic so you can switch between them at any time and use their abilities to make your way through the levels.  Puzzles are quite varied requiring a number of different strategies, especially if you want to collect all the experience orbs which can be quite difficult to reach.  All of the characters are well-balanced and necessary to proceed through the game.  The game is also very well-written and acted which is a welcome change from most platformers.

Where Trine really shines though is the graphics.  The art in this game is absolutely stunning and it's amazing how well it runs even on older hardware.  It also makes use of nVidia PhysX for high quality physics simulation (nVidia hardware not required.)  The world and levels are very well designed and quite engrossing as well.

The only thing this game is missing is coop, but that was added for the sequel which is just as awesome.  Play them both!  You won't regret it.

reviewText:
What a beautiful game. If there are any people out there who have read my other reviews with any regularity, you know that I am not a fan of puzzle platformers. With early access and indie development being so accessible, the market is flooded with crappy 2D platformers and just the thought of them puts a sour taste in many peoples mouths.

Trine enters the “2 1/2”D realm because the environment and models are all done in gorgeous 3D and it is only movement which is restricted to a flat plane. The gameplay actually surprised me because it focuses a good amount on combat, bringing in a sort of metroidvania feel without the exhaustive and often tedious backtracking. You can freely swap between one of three characters: a knight, thief and wizard. The knight is a go-to for combat while the thief covers mobility and the wizard... well he makes boxes. I found myself almost exclusively using the thief while only briefly swapping to the wizard to spawn in a box or plank. Meanwhile the knight sat around in limbo collecting dust between boss fights. It really felt like the characters were extremely balanced on paper but in practice the thief really is the main character, only needing the wizard to make some new platforms and the knight to smack around anything she can’t keep at bay with her bow.

The good parts of Trine are really good, and while I feel that the characters aren’t balanced quite right this doesn’t take away from the writing, animation and overall quality this game brings to the table.

reviewText:
It's very difficult to know where to start. On one hand, I feel like putting some thoughts together regarding Trine is well overdue, whilst on the other hand, it's actually fairly daunting. Trine has appealed to me in more ways than I expected when I first sat down to play it, and even now, on my third or fourth playthrough, I still find myself swept away by the game's grandeur.

Trine's outstanding visual aesthetics and compelling soundtrack are just the tip of the iceberg as solid gameplay and well implemented puzzles expose the game's true beauty.

Full review with screenshots here: http://twolofbees.com/cheesetalks/trine.php

reviewText:
Trine is a game about three typical fantasy hero archetypes (the mage, the thief, and the knight) on a typical quest through typical locales to get (as typically) three artifacts. Along the way, you'll use typical weapons and fight typical enemies while solving typical puzzles and looking for typical secrets.

Despite all this, Trine is fantastic. You play as one hero at a time, swapping on the fly, and they each play differently; the Thief has a grappling hook and a bow, the Knight is an excellent melee fighter and can lift and destroy heavy objects, and the Wizard can create and move platforms, crates, and the like.

The game itself is beautiful, mostly thanks to stunning art and level design, and the soundtrack is excellent, fitting the game thematically and doing its part to add an overall sense of exploration. The gameplay is top-notch, although the platforming can be a bit floaty at times.

The game is a decent length (6-8 hours or so) and never really overstayed its welcome, and finishes with a fantastic level that's much different from any previous one. Throughout the game, you'll level up your characters and find hidden items that you can equip to any of the three for stat and ability boosts.

I really enjoyed my time with Trine and recommend it at almost any price, but I did have one gripe with it: the heroes are vastly varied, but unfortunately that applies to how fun they are, too. The Wizard is by far the least fun to play, although he's probably the most useful; the Knight I had the least amount of fun with, until I got a late-game upgrade that made him feel, at least, powerful; but I almost exclusively used the Thief, whose grappling hook and ranged weapon made her incredibly fun to play and almost made the other characters obsolete for platforming and most combat scenarios.

That, however, is only a personal problem and completely subjective. Other people might find the Wizard to be the most fun, given his versatility, or the Knight, since he can throw rocks and smash skeletons to pieces in an instant.

I wholeheartedly recommend Trine to anyone who enjoys solid platformers with a tiny bit of puzzling, fantasy themes, or beautiful scenery.

Nine out of ten.

reviewText:
Just finished Trine in the free-weekend.

I wanted to play this game for a while, and I took advantage of this opportunity to finally try it out. I am not disappointed, but I'm not fully pleased either.

TL;DR review = Beautiful looking game, impressive degree of immersion for the genre through graphics, sounds and writing. Gameplay mechanics are not terrible, but they are the weakest link in this game. Not a deal breaker though, game is worth a try.

TL review:

Gameplay:
I know quick-time events are not a necessity for side-scrolling platformers, but when you have a rich 3d environment and heavy physics, they become important. Case in point, the grapling hook from the Thief seems often buggy (often goes through stuff you can jump on, breaks with no clear reason, etc), staying on platform edges or jumping on them can be more tricky than it should, and creating platforms with the wizard can prove difficult if there's the slightest denivalation in the terrain (boxes start to roll, etc). Combat is pretty repetitive and non-interesting, you don't have a lot of moves/attacks, and enemies have an attack animation that doesn't really land with the effect.One more thing; this might be an intended mechanic, or because of time and/or development constraints was not implentend: moving/dropping non-attached stuff with your wizard. It kind of feels like moving an object in editing software; physics are mostly there for the move part, but the drop part is just like dropping from a fixed point with no velocity, no matter what.

Graphics
This is where the game shines. It looks gorgeus. There's a heavy accent on colours and detail, a beautiful 3d environment with a fixed side-scrolling 2d camera. The style gives every setting the feeling of magic, especially the outdoor forest parts. It's also not extremely demanding, at least in the original version; I was able to run it with an acceptable framerate on an outdated low-end laptop, and it looked great. Enchanted Edition wasn't all that spec friendly :D.

Design
Story - Not bad. It's sort of like a narrative that you knew as a child, a tale of heroes bound together, who overcome obstacles to reach individual goals, but find that their bond changes their perception, and seemingly work together for the greater good.
Sounds - The music in this game is great. It fits perfectly with the story/writing, and with the adequate graphics behind it, it's conveying a sense of immersion. The sound effects and voice acting aren't bad either, but it's the music that truly shines.
Levels - The levels are not too difficult, ergo this game is not too difficult. You may find it troublesome to get some achievements, but all in all it's pretty balanced, at last until the last level, which seems to jump the volume of difficulty to 150% (from 100% obviously...idk, I had no better analogy...). Again, it's not THAT difficult, it's just that the game progresses really smoothly in difficulty, not really increasing or decreasing by much, and at the last one, BOOM, it's like you switched from normal to hard (this game doesn't have a difficulty option, btw).

Conclusion
Well...what can I say, I enjoyed it, even though gameplay mechanics kind of frustrated me. I'll put some of that on my rig though, and considering I'm recommending this game, what I found problematic isn't that much of a problem.

reviewText: I fell in love with the Rock-Paper-Scissors digital edition that is Trine back when it came out on 360 and it must have been the shader quality that is still there to this day, but something about it had me hooked. It has very well lit levels, and yet all the levels are dark, with fire everywhere, and enemies intertwined on different platforms, with swings, slides, and other sorts of mechanical objects to manipulate, but the way the light plays on the surfaces makes it into pure videogame artistry. With a difficulty at higher levels that makes even me cringe at the repressed memories of what it takes to beat the last level of this game without dying, it could take a normal gamer over 80 hours to even get close to perfect completion. I only stood a chance because I almost beat in on 360 when it came out, investiong about 80 hours, but by comparision the 360 version looks too ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to enjoy as purely as this. Before the Enchanted Edition I could run this game at max settings, not anymore. That's amazing. They really cranked the fidelity and extended the life of a game that didn't even need to be revived, I wish this would happen with more games.

reviewText: What an absolute joy to play and a really beautiful looking game. As far as platformers go this has actually been more fun for me, if of course less challenging, than Super Meat Boy which is one of the best platformers of all time. The colours, sound and voice acting are all so well created and put together that I struggle to find any flaws with the presentation and audio. The story is very simple as you would imagine so if you're looking for some sort of epic tale then this is probably not going to be first on your list. Controls are fluid although you cannot use a controller, something which I believe they fixed in the second edition to this series. I couldn't reccomend this game more to people who enjoy platformers or want to support good indie gaming or hell even people who just like looking at something pretty. Replay value is pretty high as there are tons of secrets and achievements to conquer as well as hard and very hard difficulty modes respectively. Overall a brilliant game and well worth the asking price on Steam.

reviewText:
After having neglected this game for a long time, I decided to give it a try. So, here are my impressions.
Visuals: This game is a real feast for the eyes. I find it redundant to describe it in detail, since it's overall beautiful.
Gameplay: The control interface is comfortable and is neither too simple, nor needlessly complicated. The interaction of the characters with their envoirment is on a highly satisfying level, be it objects or enemies. What surprised me in a pleasant way are the physics in the game, making the platforming and puzzles a fun and challenging experience. The combat is rather simple, but decently done for this type of game.
Sound: No objections, just like a cherry on top of the cake it rounds up an enjoyable game.

So far it sounds like this is a perfect game. But, it does have it flaws, mainly the sadistic difficulty of the final level. Be warned, this is one unforgiving level with literally no room for error. The reason why it is signifficantly harder than the rest of the game is that not only it punishes every big mistake with the need to restart the level, and that it is quite fast-paced compared to the other levels. Another point is the replay value. Once you've completed the game, that is all what the story can offer, it has no extra content, only higher difficulty. That hardly means the replay value is zero, on the contrary. Unless you replay it several times in rapid succession, you can always rediscover this games charms and try to complete every challenge it offers.

The verdict: 8/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Played the game on hardest difficulty from start to finish. Interesting little game though the challenges don't get too much more interesting. Figuring out how to get chests and experience bottles seems to be the most puzzling part and I felt I cruised through the rest. The constant respawn at the checkpoints is nice, but takes away from the challenge of playing on hardest difficulty. The last level and the secret level were both slightly more exciting with a up down scroller as opposed to the typical left to right, but I feel it could of been added earlier. The whole (running against the clock) near the end as well also could of been utilizes more as it added intensity to the gameplay.

Also, I feel there should of been more boss presence in the game. A couple LARGE minions that could be counted as 'mini bosses' perhaps, but nothing that really bosslike impacted me throughout the game once.

I also have Trine 2 and look forward to playing it. I look forward to seeing how coop may differ from regular gameplay and what kind of advantages that would have. I would not rate this in my top games, and I DID get it on a sale for both Trine 1 and 2 on a 3 dollar deal... But I believe trine 1 is worth at least a 5 dollar purchase.
Fun but not OVERLY exciting. I played a couple levels at a time and had to put it down.

I would rate the game a 6.5/10 and would recommend for a younger audience, or people just wanting to burn casual time. Still fun, but not overly EXCITING.

reviewText:
Trine brings platforming games to the front page. I feel like I'm going to say a lot of the same as what you'll read in other magazines.

Its beautiful... its thoughtfully designed... though I won't say its challenging. Its easy just like a lot of games of our current day. When you have been gaming since the 1980s and things like ghosts and goblins I don't think anything is as challenging.

It will keep your attention for some time as there are many different ways to get through the levels. It gives you options which is nice for this day and age. Though generally you will find that the warrior is less played and that you spent most of your time either as the rogue or the wizard as they are the most playable. It may sound like I'm bashing the game a little but in the end I enjoyed it a lot. Probably the most through the achievement challenges and trying to beat the last level without taking any damage.

If you buy it and you like platforming games you'll love it.

reviewText:
This game is the reason I have bought a lot of other puzzle/platform games which didn't interest me in the past. Bought it on sale, decided to give it a crack and haven't looked back.

Stunning visuals, devious puzzles with an almost perfect learning curve make this game amazing. Essentially the game revolves around having three charactors, Thief, Warrior and Wizard who all have unique abilities. The Thief can shoot a bow, and use a grapple to swing around and over obstacles, the Warrior is your melee charactor, with sword, shield and hammer, which can be used to bash through certain obstacles, and the Wizard who can leveitate objects and create boxes and ramps. As the game progresses, some of the chests you find will equip you with loot that enhance existing abilities, and also allow you to use them in different ways. This is alongside a relatively basic levelling system, which allows you enhance your abilities also.

Some of the puzzles will have you using all three charactors to solve.

The achievements blend well with the game, and will have you playing each level over over to find all the secrets and experience. Finding some of the secrets will leave you scratching your head, until ultimately leading to the AHA! moment when you finally work out how to get there/find it.

9.5/10 for me and definately worth buying. The fact that it comes on sale for $1 relatively regularly means this game just needs to be your inventory no matter what.

reviewText:
Trine is a 2D platformer created by Frozenbyte.

BY POWER OR THREE HEROES...
In Trine, player controls three different characters. The Wizard, who can create boxes and levitate things in the air. The Thief, who can shoot arrows and use her crabling hook. And The Knight, who's speciality is killing monsters and lifting heavy objects. Using these three different characters in puzzle solving and platforming player must make his way to several different gorgeus looking levels.

BEDTIME STORIES
Game's story in other hand, is kinda cliche. Three main character are by accident been connected to the magical artefact, Trine. By working together, they must find way to stop Undead army and find artefacts which could undo Trine's spell. Story won't seems like much first, but feels like it was rip off from bedtime storybook and sucks player into himself by it's charm and music.

DIFFERENT KINDA PUZZLER
Trine mixes in it's gameplay puzzle solving, platforming and hack 'n slash. Especially in puzzle solving game shines. Mixing all three characters player can find several different solutions in puzzles, but was those solved by own way, progressing feels satisfying. Game have couple problems which could be worth to mentioning. First, enemy waves have bad habit to continue even then, when player have had enough, and second, game don't have any kinda online co-op, which is shame, because this game almost sceam for the online co-op. Levels are full of secrets like exp-bottles and special items which give game small RPG-feeling.

VERDICT:
Trine is a beautiful and personal looking puzzle platformer with it's couple annoying parts and not having online co-op. I suggest everyone who have any kinda interest to puzzle games and/or platform games.
7.9/10

reviewText:
Trine is a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game, developed by Frozenbyte.
Gameplay

The player controls and switches between three different characters (a thief, a knight, and a wizard) to try to complete levels. There is also a cooperative play feature, whereby multiple players can join in at any time to control different characters simultaneously. Each character has their own health and energy meter. Energy is used for certain weapons and abilities, and is replenished by blue-colored bottles found throughout levels. Health is replenished by collecting heart-shaped containers, which result from destroying certain enemies.

This game is basically like a strategic puzzle solving story that just gets funner the more you play it. I bought it for i think .99 USD and for that price and this quality of gaming, i would HIGHLY!! recommend this game to anyone who enjoys this type of game. A solid 8/10

reviewText:
Marvelous (not so) little platformer. I was quite sceptical how the some kind of fairy tail/rpg-ish setting would match a platformer. Silly me, cause it perfectly did and furthermore the setting should not remain the games only strength.

As you may have already read, you are not going to play not one, but three-in-one character(s) - leeding to some refreshing game mechanics. As such you follow a not particulary special yet beautifuly told story through several stages with more or less (but rather less) difficult puzzles. Though the difficulty of the game in general is all in all rather not as challenging as other platformers might be it never felt unsatisfying.

After all and especially consindering the price (even when there is no on-going sale) you really can't do much wrong with this gem. Even if you're not the one for platformers I'm almost sure Trine's charm and artstyle will win you over.
