reviewText:
I was very happy from start to finish playing Trine.

Trine is a relatively short platformer that uses 3 distinct characters with unique skills to help you progress and collect all the experience bottles throughout each level. You can change characters on the fly just by pressing 1, 2 or 3.

The visuals are stunning and I was constantly just looking at the scenery. The sound is equally good, with fantastic music that suited each level. It's worth noting the sound effects were all great and of very high quality.

There are several different enemies and bosses" throughout the game. However
date:
the enemies lack variety and will constantly repeat over and over. I put bosses in quotes because they are actually quite easy. Maybe mini-bosses is a better term.

Trine is a very forgiving game (played on the default difficulty). It's easy to pick up and play a level. It never gets very difficult and has a very generous checkpoint/revival system.

The story is as good as it can be for a game like this. There's not much too it
recommended:
but it’s conveyed well to the player through a fantastic narrator.

The controls are ok. Sometimes I got frustrated with my character motion and jumping onto ledges. But it is a minor gripe.

To fix my framerate stutter
+I ran an uncapped fps and left it to vsync to run at 60fps. This caused stuttering every couple of seconds. I fixed this by telling Trine in the options to run at a capped 60fps. Completely smooth after that

Fix input lag
+Another easy fix. My mouse input lag was pretty bad. Trine has an option to reduce lag. You'll want to put a check mark in that box


Pros
+Beautifully styled graphics.
+Sound design is solid.
+Overall platforming is fun.
+Game rewards you (with experience) for exploring corners and trying to find the secret chests.
+Smooth 60fps
+Stable. Never crashed on my Windows 8.1 machine
+Great narrator voice acting.
+Fun puzzles and having to think how to progress further

Cons
+Not much to the story.
+At times I fought with the controls
+Default difficulty could be a little more challenging
+Only a few useful power-ups. A lot of them don't affect the characters much. (This may change when played on a harder difficulty)
+Very few unique enemies.

Final score: 8/10

I would absolutely recommend Trine. The regular price of $14.99 seems a little much. I would not pass this up if it goes on sale. I got the Trine collections for $2.49 during the 2014 Summer Sale.
"

reviewText:
This game is beautiful. It's fun. It manages not to frustrate the hell out of you. Plus the lovely Thief has the voice of Isabela from Dragon Age 2. You can shoot skeletons, smash 'em, chop 'em or just drop something heavy onto them. The puzzles are not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like they are in some games and... wheee grappling hoooooooo...

Quite frankly, the visuals are stunning. I'm normally not one to focus on graphics but Trine is really excellent. Which is good, because it's not one of the soulless, mass-produced turds that get released so much lately.

That could tempt you to think it's just the visuals. but no, as I said - while it depends on the player, I found the balance between combat, puzzles and platforming quite appealing. There are also things to pick up for all the completionists, so you might find yourself replaying Trine if you're that kind of a person.

I guess my main gripe with the game could be that it doesn't really have big flaws. It's not frustrating, you might actually consider that one. I don't. The game isn't really particularly hard, except possibly finding all the hidden thingamajigs. While there's not much of variety in opponents, they're not exactly the main focus either and the levels actually show variety. Which is pretty good, as copy-pasting is a pretty nasty sin.

Trine hits quite a few nice spots and it calls back to the nostalgia days of Super Mario, just without taking the wrong cues - instead of picking up the ugly graphics and frustration, it takes the spirit of platforming and adds a spin on it. And while it uses physics for its puzzles, it avoids the pitfalls of that fairly well, delivering quite consistent results to what you do. It also gives you freedom to approach a few places in different ways, which is good - but as my memory serves, that resulted in me mostly using the Thief and the Wizard, with the Knight just doing bugger all except freak accidents when he was actually needed.

The game is pretty good, if a little short. I'm a bit on the fence whether it's a good thing or not, but then again it does avoid the pitfall of stretching everything too far and lets you have some carefree fun in between things. It's not even particularly rough around the edges, so it's definitely worth checking out.

reviewText: Trine is another sidescroller with many puzzle and jump elements. You probably will not find very new elements in this game that havent been playable before. However even the game adds nothing new to the gaming world i was fascinated by the beautifully created scenaries. The story of the game is not very deep and you wont see cutscenes at all. The music is very atmospheric and a great addition to the scenary. The voices of the characters and narrator are suiting well and are available in different languages. (I played on German and English language settings.) Mostly i enjoyed the multiplayer mode where you can join or host a public or private game and team up with 2 other players. Its a nice way to get to know different people or have fun with your friends. You can plan a strategy to find your path and even different strategies might lead to success. The different abilities of the 3 charakters have their own strengths and weaknesses which you will get to find out very quickly. I purchased the game in a bundle package with Trine 2 for only 3,22 euros and gave it a try but even without the discount i have to say, Trine is definately worth its money.

reviewText: Side scrolling platformer where you control three characters in a fantasy setting. In theory each character has their strong points and should contribute to specific areas of the game... However in reality for the majority of the game you could pick which of the three you like the best and roll through levels with them. Compounding on this problem is the fact that the Knight character is mostly useless leaving you to use him to eat damage. The narrative is clever with good voice over work between levels but can't seem to figure out if it's trying to be humorous or quaint. The graphics are beautiful but many parts made me wish I had been able to walk into the back/foreground (like Bug 3D).\n\nIf you enjoy platformers or RPGs this will be worth checking out since it combines elements of both well.

reviewText: This game is truly a game of art. With wonderful graphics, sound effects, soundtrack, and a trio of characters flourishing with life, Trine really does everything right. The platforming is one of a kind, find your own way through the levels, with every level and area available to be transformed and manipulated to your own play style, with whichever character your prefer the most. Although the story is quite dark, the world is being sucked of its magic and happiness, the developers have really gone out of their way to make this story fantasticly fun, and the comedy and witty banter between characters cuts through the doleful yet beautiful and comedic storyline. If you haven't already gotten Trine, give it a try. I'm looking forward to both the 2nd and 3rd installments.

Still, love this game for those Main menu moments.

10/10 Would fly as Zoya in Main Menu again.

reviewText: Trine!! Such a great idea and also well implemented... what else can you ask for? This is one of those games that are kind of special to me, along with its sequel Trine 2. Athough the game was launched in 2009, the developers updated the game not long ago with a lot of new stuff. I never really paid too much attention to the story of the game, but that's just because the game is so fun that I was always eager to get started. The gameplay mechanics are great, I love how each character does different things and serves a different role within the group. In fact, I'd recommend playing this game with your significant other/housecarl. This is one of those great co-op games, definitely perfect for a couple or maybe even some friends... so long as there are just 3 of you!\n\nIt is true that the game is not hard at all, with the exception of the last stages,  but even on easy it'll take you some time to find everything in the game and discover all its secrets. I just managed to get all the achievements and it took me about 15 hours, but I'd say the main game would take you about 6 or 7 hours. Definitely more if you replay some of the stages, or if you like to go treasure hunting like me!  Oh, and in case none of your friends have the game but you still want to collaborate with other people while playing, remember that Trine also has an online mode. Besides all this, the game is in a lot of different languages and the dubbing is also very good in all the versions I've heard so far. I'd mention its cons, but I simply don't see any. Don't think about it too much, just choose the knight, the thief or the wizard and find that elusive Trine before it's too late!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: You remember years ago, when you used to sit down for an hour or two and play a videogame? After school and before dinner, kicking off your shoes and curling up with Crash or Ratchet until the TV went off and the food was done? Not a 6 hour binge or a 12 hour marathon session, but just a wind-down and chill out session of zen gaming? Well if you need to be remended then I highly recommend Trine. This gorgeous plateformer delivers level after stunning level of puzzle-platform fun in a relatively short but action packed package. I played through with an xbox360 controller and was pleasantly reminded of the console platformers I grew up on.\n\nAll in all a game well worth your time and dollar. Others have fairly reviewed in more detail, see those reviews for pros and cons. I will leave you with nothing more than my heartiest recommendation and wishes of good gaming :)

reviewText: You remember years ago, when you used to sit down for an hour or two and play a videogame? After school and before dinner, kicking off your shoes and curling up with Crash or Ratchet until the TV went off and the food was done? Not a 6 hour binge or a 12 hour marathon session, but just a wind-down and chill out session of zen gaming? Well if you need to be remended then I highly recommend Trine. This gorgeous plateformer delivers level after stunning level of puzzle-platform fun in a relatively short but action packed package. I played through with an xbox360 controller and was pleasantly reminded of the console platformers I grew up on.\n\nAll in all a game well worth your time and dollar. reviewText: Trine!! Such a great idea and also well implemented... what else can you ask for? This is one of those games that are kind of special to me, along with its sequel Trine 2. Athough the game was launched in 2009, the developers updated the game not long ago with a lot of new stuff. I never really paid too much attention to the story of the game, but that's just because the game is so fun that I was always eager to get started. The gameplay mechanics are great, I love how each character does different things and serves a different role within the group. In fact, I'd recommend playing this game with your significant other/housecarl. This is one of those great co-op games, definitely perfect for a couple or maybe even some friends... so long as there are just 3 of you!\n\nIt is true that the game is not hard at all, with the exception of the last stages,  but even on easy it'll take you some time to find everything in the game and discover all its secrets. I just managed to get all the achievements and it took me about 15 hours, but I'd say the main game would take you about 6 or 7 hours. Definitely more if you replay some of the stages, or if you like to go treasure hunting like me!  Oh, and in case none of your friends have the game but you still want to collaborate with other people while playing, remember that Trine also has an online mode. Besides all this, the game is in a lot of different languages and the dubbing is also very good in all the versions I've heard so far. I'd mention its cons, but I simply don't see any. Don't think about it too much, just choose the knight, the thief or the wizard and find that elusive Trine before it's too late!

Cheers to the developers for making a fun game though, I hear Trine II is quite awesome as well.

reviewText: First word that comes to mind when I think about this game is... Beautiful! The graphics in this game are trully outstanding. The setting takes place in a magical world, and visuals transport the player right into it.\nApart from this, the gameplay is very original, and although it takes a little while to get used to, once you get into the game it can be a true godsend :) I would class this game as a casual action / puzzle / platformer. It is an easy-to-play kind of game, during which you can just relax and enjoy the scenery. This may be a downside to those who enjoy a challenge (especially when it comes to enemies, as these don't really get any harder throughout the game), but overall it is an utterly enjoyable experience.\nThere is also a lot of storyline which is definitely worth following.

reviewText:
A True Masterpiece!
This game has everything you need.
It's really fun to play!
The game itself is a stimulating platform game, with puzzles and enemies, in which you alternate between 3 very different characters, each one with his own abilities.
The game is not too hard, but not too easy either...i'd say it's well balanced.
Longevity is also satisfying, with a good amount of levels.
The graphics are gorgeous, with a lot of depth into the scenaries, and the level design proves to be one of the best ever, even today; It takes a different approach towards the classic medieval theme, concentratic more on the magical and colorful fable-like" flavour rather than the dark gritty one (more popular in other games).
The music is something you can easily label as MAGNIFICENT
recommended: MERVELOUS!\nOne of the best soundtrack i have ever listened to...you'll surely end up listening to it long after finishing the game.\nA very good product! :)"

reviewText:
This review is for the original, non-enchanted edition as I had already started with the original and never found the time to finish it of until now. I may go through the game again on enchanted to see what differences there are besides better graphics....and while I'm at it, I might as well go for 100% completion so that means getting the remaining achievements I haven't already got from running with the original....

Oooohhh, I don't know why I started this on Hard difficulty(but didn't change it because I don't like changing difficulty half way through a game so I stuck with it)....hahaha - guess I thought I could take the heat! Apparently not so died so many times! hahaha... Actually I probably won't bother with 100% achievement completion(But I will try to get as close to that though) as I just took a glance and one of them was completing it on the hardest difficulty, which would be the next level up from Hard as this is the 2nd hardest(unless there's harder - there's apparently hardcore mode mentioned in the descriiption of that achievement....).

Anyways, it's a puzzle, platformer, action and adventure game. That's what the genres should be, but it was tagged as only action adventure... So you start the game when the three characters collide with each other and combined into one being(I can't remember the exact details on how this happened as I started the game a couple or so years ago but never finished it), they are the Thief, Knight and Wizard. Thief's a  woman and the other two are guys. So are set out to find the other two powers(I forgot what the other two were called - lol and just finished a several minutes ago! haha), you have Trine. After that, the three beings as one will seperate into themselves again.

So gameplay is you can do local coop, or coop on seperate PCs and can play each of three characters, or if you don't have people to play with you can solo it, like I did. When soloing, you can switch between the three to use their unique abilities and strengths to overcome obstacles in your way. I would imagine it would be more fun and quicker/easier if you had someone or two to play with and they control the other two characters... If you know platform type games like oldschool mario, then I don't need to explain any further as it's similar to that, with added puzzles. If not, then you basically jump and down - killing and or avoiding enemies, solving puzzles, and the screen sidescrolls for you automatically as you progress into the level.

Graphics, yeah I thought the original Trine graphics was nice and pretty with everything maxed. Had average fps  of about 67-ish. The physic in this game, which uses nVidia's PhysX system, was awesome! Another one of those rare PhysX games.

Audio, well I can say that it actually made full use of my 7.2 surround sound setup - surprised as it's a sidescroller platformer type game which I would have though stereo would be enough, but nope! The atmosphere and music was great! The voice overs were cool too. Sound effects were nice. I believe it must be thanks to the EAX checkbox I ticked....

Um not sure what else to say...I liked it enough to give it a thumbs up, though some of the parts are fustration especially the timing bits and to add skeletons attacking you at the sametime that you have to avoid or and kill off....hah....the last level.....oh god......almost raged but got through it in the end! hahahaha Oh and once you've finished the game, you unlock a harder difficulty, Very Hard - which I'm not even gonna bother with(Hard was fustrating enough for me thanks!)...hahahaha...also there's a new level that unlocks which appears to be similar to the last level of the game.........................................................

So yeah....you like solving puzzles? Like a bit of adventure, action too? Do you like them platformer type sidescrolling games as well? Well this is for you!

reviewText:
Great artwork with the game, it's really really well done. The game is in 2D which is not a problem and you have to travel from the point left to the right, while climing fighting monsters and solving puzzels.

Pros:
-Great environement!
-Unique Story
-Smooth controls
-Archer charater well balanced

Cons:
Wizard charater and Breserker (fighter) Charater not balanced at all.
I was playing this game with some friend so one took the archer the other the wizard so I took the breserker and my charater is suppose to be the best fighter since it's hes speciality.

Mouvement: Because the breseker cannot jump as high while doing parkours and puzzels and hes really heavy so to get him around he needs assitance on each levels. (wizard need to move him around) And trust me there is no other way.

Combat: Sure your sword can bash into the skeletons quite easily but the wizards can easily block them with hes cubs and kill them drop cubs on him. So in combat your not that useful since there is also the archer shooting arrows behind to aid.

Boss Fight: You do not damange the bosses (mini bosses so far) so you just block and jump around and hope to live an other day while the wizard tries to block him with hes cubs and the archer to kill him.

Breserker: This charater is pretty much useless and destroy some of the trio coop gameplay because when you play the wizard you do 70% of the work the archer does 29% and the bresker does the last 1% because all you do is try to jump but it fails so you wait to be moved by the wiz, in combat you try to help but they other can handel it and in boss your kinda just here to watch.


---------------------------------------------------------Conclusion-------------------------------------
Great game but unbalanced charaters in a trio coop so if you end up with the wrong charater you will be watching the others play.  I recomand to play this with a single friend not two.        75/100

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Side scrolling platformer with great graphics and some tricky (but not too tricky) puzzle solving and light combat. Great game for casual co-op as well.

You play a trio of heroes trapped in a single body by a mysterious magical artifact called the Trine. While your souls are bound, you can be any one of the three characters at any time: Wizard, Thief, or Knight. Your quest is to find out why you’re bound together and how to undo the “curse.”

The game is played with keyboard and mouse though other players can drop in using a game controller on the same computer. You progress mostly from left to right in a two dimensional plane with a lot of jumping and scrambling from one level to another. With a press of a button you can instantly switch between the three characters, each with their unique skills useful for fighting (knight) grappling (thief) or conjuring objects to use (wizard). Each of the characters has their own life bar so if they die you need to either make do with the other 2 characters or backtrack until you get to a checkpoint (a glowing sphere). You can backtrack as much as you want in this game, which is useful since there are a lot of collectibles to be found. The collectibles mainly come in the form of experience potions, and when you level up you can upgrade skills unique to each character class (for example increasing the number of objects the wizard can have conjured at any one time).

Pros:
+Amazing graphics for a little indie game. The environments look 3D despite being a simple side scroller.
+Free upgrade to the Enchanted Edition. The upgraded version uses the Trine 2 engine and got a large number of new Steam achievements.
+Nice story with good narration. The narrator appears as an announcer in Dota 2 so you may recognize his voice.

Cons: Not much really, the game is awesome.

This is a great, cheap game that anyone can get into. If you didn’t get it for free sometime in the past you can probably see it in Humble Bundles occasionally. Play with friends and family!

reviewText:
I personally like new twists on old classics, so I look for influences of good oldies in newer games. So when I was first introduced to “Trine”, I was all like: here are new “The Lost Vikings” (by Blizzard, 1992): three characters, each one with his strength and weaknesses complementing each other and solving little puzzles to complete levels.

“Trine” is not, of course a copy of “Vikings”: it is more of an action, the puzzles are a bit easier, characters transform to each other, not being present on screen simultaneously (much like Silmarils’ “Metal Mutant” of 1991). Of course game looks much and much better, the world is designed beautifully,

Game’s characters get experience from killing monsters and finding secrets, which can also contain unique items. Level-ups make them stronger in combat and platforming.

So if you are into mildly difficult puzzle-platformers with a bit of RPG elements, you should check this one out.

reviewText:
Short version: 91%Trine is an enchanting old-school platformer with three unique main characters and excellent level design. It suffers from some difficulty issues, especially in the end, yet those can be easily forgiven when you get yourself lost in the immersive visuals.

Long version:Indie platformers on PC are far from being rare, but seldom do we see a gem like Trine. The largest selling point of the game is the breathtaking visual style and carefully constructed, detail-rich levels. The backgrounds are just teeming with and movement, making you feel you are playing in a living 3D environment, even though the gameplay itself is limited to 2D.

The game itself is a very traditional platformer, where the levels require agility and a bit of resilience to get through. You also get three characters with distinctive abilities, but they all seem to lack personality. Although the original design suggests that all three are needed to clear the levels, in reality most stages are beatable by using mostly, or only the Thief. Despite this shortcoming, the level design is fun, and gathering all the (optional) experience can be a challenging, but not impossible task.

The only part where the game falls short– like most platformers– is the story, which really boils down to: “Evil wizard is evil, go kill.” Still, the narration is pleasant and the banter among the three reluctant heroes is entertaining enough to keep you interested in the simple plot line.

You can also switch to the Enchanted edition in the Betas tab, where the engine is replaced by the sequel’s, but even though I can run Trine 2 with no problems, the Enchanted edition suffered massive frame drops for me, so I can’t judge the upgrade.

reviewText: Trine caught my attention cause I love platform games.  This one took me by surprise. reviewText:
Quick review:

Short Verdict: One of the best games I've ever played! It's a mix of all the genres I love: RPG, puzzle, platformer, exploration, and it also has some fighting. I've loved it so much I beat it twice in a row! I started playing the Original Game (OG), which was amazing, then I moved to Enchanted Edition (EE), which was even better (if you wanna play the game just once, go for EE, although playing both might be worth, since they still feel slightly like different games). I'll definitely play Trine 2 when I have the chance! (Note: I haven't tried playing it online, so I can't comment on that)

Pros:
Great balanced mix of different game genres
Beautiful graphics
Awesome BGM
Three different interchangeable characters who are likeable and have their unique set of upgradable skills
15+1 long and well-planned distinct levels with their own atmosphere and a lot of secrets to find
Collectible equipment to further customize your characters
Really addicting, it doesn't get old even if you're replaying a level
Nice voice acting, especially the narrator's
Even though the game is old, the devs are still responsive at the forums, especially after EE, I guess
Cons:
Zoya, the Thief, is a bit overpowered
I wish there was more to the story--I thought it was a bit shallow and I wanted more
A bit easy for me, even on hard (haven't tried the OG-exclusive Very Hard Mode though)
(OG ONLY!) Moving objects is slower than needed to be (a lot faster on EE)
(OG ONLY!) Conjuring objects with the controller is a pain (improved on EE)
(OG ONLY!) Bats are really annoying and seem a bit broken (they've been removed from EE)
Bought on / for: Humble Store for US$ 0.99. But it's definitely worth the full price they're asking for!

reviewText: A beatiful game, to play with friends or alone. Trine seems inspired by the classic Blizzard game The Lost Vikings. reviewText: I'm sure this is going to get downvoted by diehard fanboys of this series, but really. The graphics are nice, yes. The music's decent. There's a good premise for a game here. So why is it /so bloody boring/? There's very little variation in the levels here, aside from one or two notable exceptions most every level plays the same. Even then the only notable departure is the last level, which is instead just flat-out flawed. The game focuses far too much on its combat system and too little on platforming or creative puzzle design. There's about three different types of enemies throughout the entire game, and they're all over the place in each level. So fighting them gets... really boring, really fast. Though the bats never stop being annoying. Ever. The puzzle design is mostly physics-based and can also be entirely broken, basically defeating the point. I have plenty of fun playing as the thief and doing neat platformery stuff, but that's fairly limited throughout the game... I kind of wish the game was based more around that mechanic than the combat or physics puzzles, really. But as it stands the game just felt like it dragged on forever to me despite not even having that massive of a play time to it overall. Not going to say it's outright terrible but it's not particularly impressive either.

reviewText:
Most beautiful puzzle platformer I've ever played. Damn, I love this game. Seriously. I want to hug it and kiss it, it's THAT good. The game is simple. You complete levels by solving the puzzles. And these puzzles are mostly solved using physics. Depending on the puzzle, you choose one of three characters (you can switch between them on the fly) to solve them. Along the way you battle enemies and collect orbs to level up. You can also find chests with items, so it also has an RPG element to it. A shame the game is over too soon, I really did not want it to end. So I had to replay it several times since then, which, of course, I didn't mind at all. Yes, this is a must have !
Bring on Trine 2 !! Woohooo !!

[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText: I highly recommend this game to everyone. As everyone knows, I like to get the flaws out in the open early. The story in this game is poor and barebones. The game is also short, as can be done in 3-4 hours. But both of this are somewhat acceptable because it is just a downloadable game that was short for $15 on release. There is a lack of variety in level design and puzzles. Besides the final level, most of the levels feel the same and after a while it might feel somewhat repetitive. If you play in short bursts it remedies this. A huge problem is that even though there are checkpoints in the levels, it will not save your progress if you exit the game. This is a problem because for a casual game, being forced to beat each level is annoying. There are only a few spells per character. Also, the thief is barely used as she is impractical. The wizard should also have an offensive spell. All that being said, it is still a surprise treat of a game.

reviewText:
Here's three reasons why Trine is not like other platforming games I've played before:

-Characters:

I usually could care less about a platforming games character, but in Trine the balance of the three characters and their unique personalities via great voice acting and unique abiliites.

-Story:

most platforming games these days are trying to do a bit better in the artwork department  and the overall artwork presentation of platforming games has progressed very well in the last few years with the advent of indie games, but Trine's artwork is best described in two words:

reviewText: Trine is basically The Lost Vikings as a physics-based puzzle platformer, offering three characters with very different skillsets and many ways you can use them to approach the game's puzzles and challenges. It's not terribly hard unless you play it on the hardest difficulties, mostly due to offering infinite lives and copious checkpoints, but it always feels like a fun adventure and doesn't lack for challenge, even if you'll be able to respawn until you complete it eventually.\n\nPlus it's got an amusing sense of humor and a solid artstyle, and with the Enchanted Edition upgrade, online multiplayer for when you want to help (or screw over) your friends through the levels. It's hard to not recommend Trine to anyone who's interested in puzzle platformers at all.

reviewText:
A fun game, with minor RPG elements, wonderful art style and visuals , albeit slightly repetitive gameplay and lack of character depth.

The first thing about this game is the amazing visuals. It is a pleasure to play simply to look at the environment. The detail to the characters, spells, enemies and background art is great. The voiceover of the characters is also very well done. All in all, the production and art, design elements are top notch.

The gameplay mechanics are well done - but the areas that could have been improved are the RPG elements. The gear and skills for each character are fairly irrelevant. It doesn't seem to be much of a stretch to say you could ignore all the gear and all the skills and finish the game without notice that you didn't use anything. They are merely small accents to your character - which is cool - but feels like it could have been developed more to make each character even more specialized and the party dynamic more rich.  As it stood, I used the fighter all the time and only switched to the mage when I needed a box and the thief when I needed to swing (and maybe at least half the time I could just make boxes to achieve the same ends).  This wasn't enough to detract from the fun of the game - it just had me thinking there was a lot of character overlap or lack of puzzle diversity to properly utilize each character more.

reviewText: Trine was absolutely spectacular. I usually do not enjoy many platformer games, but in this case, I was pleasantly surprised. The visual aspect of the game is just gorgeous. The lighting really does make it feel 'enchanted' (enchanted edition). However, this alone is not what makes this game spectacular. It is the fact that there are so many creative ways in which you can complete puzzles and get about and around in the game that made me stick around. You play as 3 people whose souls are stuck in the Trine. If you play alone, then you have to switch out between the Wizard, the Thief, and the Warrior. Each character has different special abilities, giving you the opporunity to solve the same puzzles in so many different ways. As a gamer, it really makes you feel creative when you solve a difficult puzzle/climb a difficult part of a level in your own unique way. It is all up to you in how you will get around in the game, whether it be using the Thief's grappling hook or the wizard's floating platform (etc). This game is amazing because there are no limits and no standards to how you solve a puzzle/level. It is all up to your imagination :). This is definitely worth playing!

reviewText:
Verdict: Why haven't you bought this already?!

This game has just had a completely free, absolutely stunning graphics upgrade, and co-op multi-player added where it originally had none, 5 years after original release, FOR FREE. Let this sink in for a moment, in this day and age of nickle&diming for worthless trinket pixel additions or triple A pricing for practically untouched re-releases. If you already own this, it is worth reinstalling and playing all over again; if you don't own it, it's worth every penny.

At the current sales price of 80-90% off for ALL Frozenbytes games (Trine 1&2 and Shadowgrounds), you really should just stop reading this and go buy whatever parts your collection is missing, right now. In fact, buy copies for all your friends. This company needs encouragement, and their success needs to be a bright beacon of enlightenment for games developers and publishers out there.

There's free demos to all their games if you're still doubting. Its unique experience is best understood through direct gameplay anyway. Get it, play it, then tell me again this isn't worth paying for.

Btw, performance tip: if you use the enchanted version with an NVidia GPU, make sure to add the trine1_32bit.exe file to the NVidia control panel under Manage 3D Settings, otherwise even though it uses the same engine as Trine 2, you will get a lot worse performance. The enchanted executable is in a subdirectory of the main Trine game folder. Doing this with the free downloadable nvidiaInspector and adding to the predefined Trine 2 profile is probably the best way to take advantage of the optimizations for the updated engine.

reviewText:
Released in 2009, Trine made quite the impact among the players, and then again in 2014 when Frozenbyte released the Enchanted Edition, a remake of the original using a new engine.

The peaceful kingdom is at jeopardy, the king is dead, and an army of evil and somehow cute skeletons and other creatures rise from the depths. All hope seems lost until our heroes arrive. A mysterious thief named Zoya, Amadeus the wizard, and our chubby knight Pontius. All brought together by the distant memories of the Trine, perhaps the only chance to save the kingdom, and all its people.

Trine is a side-scrolling game full of action and puzzles waiting to be solved. Thanks to each characters special ability, going through each level will require imagination. But don’t worry, planning something actually works with Trine, and maybe that’s what players really admire the most. Creating your way throw-out the 16 levels won’t be much different every time you play, but the beautiful graphics will help.
If we all have to agree on something, is that Trine looks astonishing,  with bright or dark colours, it’s all out there, to make you enjoy each level as a whole, and creating an atmosphere for the player. It’s a magical world, filled with exotic places, from dungeons to mythical forests, trough castles of bright and dangerous lights, to hidden villages with unspoken dangers, there’s fun for all the family.
The gameplay is quite intuitive, even for youngsters, which makes Trine the perfect family game. But don’t worry, the developers were nice enough to place some really hidden objects that will make you think and replace your steps with each of our three warriors. Levitate or create objects, fight your way out with the sword, hook any wood surface and swing with style, there are plenty to go around when comes to play styles.
The player can only use one character at the time, but change it at any point in the game. Make use of their skills, and improve them using a simple and minimalist (but good) menu, together with a nice inventory where you can place the items you want a certain hero to use.
There are several game modes, from the standard easy, to hardcore where your skills are tested, and maybe even your patience!
Now that we mentioned testing, why not test the original Trine? It’s included in this Enchanted Edition!

Trine is a unique experience, doesn’t matter how many games you’ve played, Trine is unique, unique to its magical bright colours, fun gameplay, and even a nice narrative that will keep you focused on the story-line.
A solid 9, and a must to your collection!

reviewText:
A big yes! Do buy this game and you will not regret it!
While you have to solve the puzzles truly  thinking  about it, you won't be hurried. You will have to be pretty precise, especially with the wizard, but not frustratingly so. Creativity is required, and there are many ways to solve a problem.
Beautiful graphics and a fary tale like narration really make this game a little gem.

The only problem I found is that, if you are playing with a controller (mine is an Xbox one), the game doesn't tell you how to use the abilities of fire arrows (Y) button, titan force (left stick, tap right stick, tap again when fully charged // LT for the quick burst), and the hammer (Y again).  It really worried me for a minute.

But then again, beside that it's truly, absolutely, completely worth it. Can't wait to play the second!

reviewText:
TL;DR: Decent pick-up on sale. Over-hyped game. Apparently Trine 2 is better.

I did not expect being disappointed by a game with 'overwhelmingly positive' reviews.

Am I the only one who noticed that there are only 4 types of enemies in the entire game? That the 1st and 2nd bosses are used several times throughout the game? That the game has no endboss despite being an action platformer? The ending is a complete joke. In addition, the tag 'puzzle' doesn't suit this game because the puzzles are either too easy or can be completely avoided in Singleplayer thanks to the thief's abilities.

This game is boring because there is an obvious lack of variety. The classes are also really unbalanced. As a consequence some are more fun (Thief) than others (Knight). The knight's gameplay is based on smashing the same button to kill ennemies. Amazing. Later on you get upgrades which allow you to insta-kill ennemies, but beware: you will need 2 buttons! Playing with the Thief or Wizard makes the fights at least a bit more entertaining.

I won't deny that the graphics are great, that the music is nice, that the story is better than for typical platformers, but none of these elements can make up for the lack of gameplay variety.

reviewText:
Relaxing, easy to get into and very fluently working platform/physics-puzzler. Gorgeous, colorful background/art design (it's a really great looking game). Not very difficult, but there are a few more tricky obstacles. You control one out of three, instantly switchable characters with different abilities to navigate the levels, manipulate it's objects, create your own or fight enemies. These three characters have some personality, but you don't get to know much of their backgrounds and they remain stereotypes mostly:

- Charming, lady-lover wizard who conjures boxes, planks and platforms. Kills enemies with physics.
- Mysterious, reserved thief who uses a grappling hook to pull and swing herself around. Kills enemies with bow.
- Overweight knight and wannabe hero who likes food and drinking. Uses shield to avoid damage. Kills enemies with sword.

The story leaves to be desired. There is one, there is a narrator speaking before each level and the characters sometimes comment things too. But it's your generic good vs evil fantasy thing. There is a name-giving Trine" artifact binding the souls of the three characters together. It sounded interesting first
date: but it's not worked out further
recommended: it's only a tool to give reason why these otherwise very different personalities come together for an adventure
hoursPlayed: and creates the outline of it."

reviewText:
Hey folks,

So I bought this game recently on sale for 85% off or something, and it was on my Wishlist and I'm glad I got it. I'd've easily paid full price for this. This game is good to play for a few minutes or as long as you want and with the ability to Save the game and pick it off where you left off is a plus.

Pros:
The graphics are pretty good and the environments are very impressive.
The mehchanics in this game are easy to learn.
Each level allows for many different ways in which it can be solved using each of the heroes abilities to make it happen, I favour the wizard.
The game loads very quickly so that you're ready to play in no time.
The abilities available in this game are simple and effective.Cons:
There are honestly no Cons I can think of at this time. This could change over time, of course.
I also managed to buy Trine 2 when it was on sale around the same time and am already looking forward to playing it. Would certainly recommend this to people who enjoy simple side-scrollers without the pressure to get through an entire level in such a short time.

reviewText:
First of all I start of by saying, this game felt so great to me I had to get all the achievements and try everything out. I did it, and boy would I do it again.

If you want an atmospheric platformer with puzzle elements this is the game for you. Not only because the game is just something you should've played. It's also a bit different than your normal platformer. Because you can switch between 3 different characters while playing with a simple push on the button. A warrior, who is strong and fierce, a mage who can't cast a fireball, and a ninja-like archer.

+ Character switching feels quick
+ The level design is amazing
+ The story is alright, but the narrating is done much better
+ The various abilities keep the game fun
+ Doesn't feel liniair

- Terrible controller controls / Magician not playable

I definitly recommend getting Trine. Besides it's on sale alot. And in my opinion it's worth it's full price.

reviewText:
Wow, I can't believe I haven't said anything about Trine yet.

On top of that - what? This game has ANY negative reviews? Wtf?

Trine. This is one of the most breathtaking, fantastic games I have seen in the past decade. It's just stunning. The graphics are incredible, the physics based stuff is all hugely entertaining, and I find obliterating skeletons to be immensely satisfying. It's just fun. I enjoyed going back to levels and redoing them time and again to find stuff I missed, because they were just that good. I play with mouse n keyboard, naturally, so I didn't really have any issues with my controls. I can't imagine trying to play Trine with a DS3 or Xbox controller.

Zoya is my favourite, naturally, Amadeus is my least favourite. Being a wizard is nice and all, but he really only exists to make boxes, for the most part. And you can end up making a -lot- of boxes. But, yeah. Pontius is okay too, and his hammer is AMAZING. It's awesome to see everything on the screen explode.

I never really had any issues with the difficulty. It's fun enough just going through the game. The story is, when you really think about it, quite plain - essentially, skeletons appeared, and then three random heroes touched a thing called the Trine and became one in a way. But I still love it. It's just so quaint, and gives me a warm happy feeling inside. What's better than a story about knights in shining armor (and his thief companion, and the cowardly wizard guy who followed them about)?

This game has no real elongated cutscenes or anything. It's just a simple platformer. You jump around the level, and hopefully you're the thief and you abuse the hell out of your grappling hook. The grappling hook is in my opinion one of the best parts of this game. It's just way too much fun to swing about with.

The soundtrack is amazing. It's just amazing. The tone of the game is perfectly in harmony with what you're seeing, and it always feels appropriate. Each level has it's own theme. I love it.

And the last level... I loved it. It was extremely challenging the first time, but that's great! I actually felt challenged, properly, not just because the devs had a range of multipliers for enemy HP and damage (which the game has anyway, but I played on hard nonetheless) but also because on this last level, the 'AI' drops stuff in front of you as you're going up this tower. If you're not fast enough, the lava rising with you gets you. It took me several tries to beat the first time, but it's absolutely just a measure of skill, even now when I'm out of practice I bet I could go back and complete again, easy. It's just about learning.

I can't recommend this game enough. Some people complained that the levels aren't varied enough, but honestly I disagree. You're not just wandering around a castle, there's quite a variety of beautiful areas to get through, and I feel like each level has it's own set of things that distinguishes it from the other levels, they really don't all feel the same to me at all. Would you say Super Mario isn't varied enough, because you just go from one end of the level to the other, platforming along the way? No, you wouldn't.

In short, Trine is an amazing game, especially at the price. It's on sale for as low as $1.50 so frequently you can set your watch by it. I think I remember this game being only $10 at one point, I don't really remember them raising it, but, hey, I'd pay $15 for it again if I knew beforehand how much enjoyment I would get from it.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Trine is enchanting in several ways, they do not lie to you when they say its the enchanted edition. The gameplay is fast and fun, using the wizard to summon blocks to jump up to unreachable hights, then shooting skeletons with the theifs bow. The puzzles are difficult and will keep you interested, while trying to find the hidden xp bottles around the place.
Trine is a very pretty game, beautiful even. The graphics are memorable and even if your not a big fan of platformers you can still get lots of enjoyment out of this game, mainly because of its well excecuted boss fights and interesting dialogue. For all ages, I would recommend this as a worthy pickup.
Here is my overall rate:
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 8/10
Dialogue 7/10
Story 6/10 (not mind blowing but interesting enough to keep me playing)

9/10 would get crushed by my own blocks again.

reviewText:
Oh wow, another physics-based puzzle/platformer you say.  Yeah, there's a million other competent games is this vein but I found Trine to be one of the better one I've played.  Most notably, the graphics are quite nice and each stage feels like it's own thing despite many using the same means of solving puzzles.

The story is completely throwaway and the character quips at the start of levels are generic, but neither get in the way of the gameplay.  Combat variety is extremely limited but I didn't have a problem with it because I had more fun just looking around the levels for hidden stuff and solving puzzles than engaging in combat.

As a bonus, the devs are updating the game with the Trine 2 engine, so in the near future, you'll be able to play the game with both engines.  The update is free and I have a lot of respect for a dev team to take the time do this for a game that is quite a few years old.  Trine is also ridiculously cheap and on sale all the time.  There's no reason to pass this game up.

reviewText:
Oh wow, another physics-based puzzle/platformer you say.  Yeah, there's a million other competent games is this vein but I found Trine to be one of the better one I've played.  Most notably, the graphics are quite nice and each stage feels like it's own thing despite many using the same means of solving puzzles.

The story is completely throwaway and the character quips at the start of levels are generic, but neither get in the way of the gameplay.  Combat variety is extremely limited but I didn't have a problem with it because I had more fun just looking around the levels for hidden stuff and solving puzzles than engaging in combat.

As a bonus, the devs are updating the game with the Trine 2 engine, so in the near future, you'll be able to play the game with both engines.  The update is free and I have a lot of respect for a dev team to take the time do this for a game that is quite a few years old.  Trine is also ridiculously cheap and on sale all the time.  There's no reason to pass this game up.

reviewText:
First of all I start of by saying, this game felt so great to me I had to get all the achievements and try everything out. I did it, and boy would I do it again.

If you want an atmospheric platformer with puzzle elements this is the game for you. Not only because the game is just something you should've played. It's also a bit different than your normal platformer. Because you can switch between 3 different characters while playing with a simple push on the button. A warrior, who is strong and fierce, a mage who can't cast a fireball, and a ninja-like archer.

+ Character switching feels quick
+ The level design is amazing
+ The story is alright, but the narrating is done much better
+ The various abilities keep the game fun
+ Doesn't feel liniair

- Terrible controller controls / Magician not playable

I definitly recommend getting Trine. Besides it's on sale alot. And in my opinion it's worth it's full price.

reviewText:
Interesting puzzles and good atmosphere make for a pleasant experience. I can't say too much about the story since I just couldn't get into it. The 'leveling' seems a bit slapped on and doesn't really add too much since you're effectively railroaded into it anyway; same could be said about the inventory. These things and the occasional focus on fighting things just don't seem to fit very well. Some skellie killing is all well and good, throwing a boss into a puzzle room is much fun, but the times when you're screen locked into fighting 1by1 spawning is weird for this kind of game.

As for the co-op... Honestly it's way easier to do yourself. And the level doesn't change with multiple people so it's completely unnecessary to have the other person. If anything you're just slowing each other down. I would not recommend this as a good co-op for those looking for a challenging puzzle game to play together. For just horsing around, sure.

Trine is not a bad game, but I wouldn't list it as the most amazing/best platformer of its time. It's interesting, a little different, and could be something to do for a little while.

reviewText: Trine is a story-telling puzzle and platformer game that I enjoyed very much in the gameplay and coop aspect. While I want to give this game my whole-hearted recommendation, I had to hesitate because I found that the game failed in the story-telling department. The first thing you notice when you start the game is the stunningly beautiful graphics which help set up this mystical atmosphere that just makes you eager to play the game. Because of that, I also grew a high expectation from the story. Sadly, as you progress through the game you start to realise that the story is almost... non-existent, in addition to a very anti-climatic and disappointing finale. I will say though, that at least the puzzles and platforming provided a decent challenge and that it was overall a pretty fun game.\n\nSo the question is, is the game worth buying? Yes, but not at the full price. It's definitely something worth trying if you like platforming and/or playing a good coop game with friends.

reviewText: I finally got around to finishing this game and I must admit, it has certainly been a lot of fun to play with interesting game mechanics. As you play as three seporate characters that you can switch between, it gives you many options to jumb between them for different ways to approch a different problem weither it be monsters or a massive pit full of spikes, a few of them will all have different approches to the situation, in some cases making way for your own solutions to the maps.\n\nThe story is both intersting with a mix of intrigue and comedy that make this game really worth it. The RPG elements are interesting too, aquiring levels by collecting these green potion bottles and applying different gear to various characters, finding what ones suit you the most. My favourite character was the thief as I loved using her arrows and grappling hook.

reviewText:
I'm starting to think physics games are doomed to fail for either not being realistic, or being too realistic. Trine somehow manages to combine both, in the worst way.

The good:
-Beautiful designs and backgrounds
-Decent narrative
-The mix of characters sometimes work well and are all utilised in finishing levels
-When the physics does work, it's very satisfying

The bad:
-The narrative is often infuriatingly interrupted by things in-game, and then not continued until the next stage
-The movement of characters, enemies, and objects is all much much too sloppy and often seems like everything's on ice, and covered in oil, making precision nigh on impossible
-The physics doesn't work 90% of the time

The game is actually impressive in how annoying it is, maybe because it has so potential that it fails to harness.

reviewText: There are two words to describe Trine and that is visual splendor. There are very few indie games out there that has this much color and graphical fidelity. Trine is extremely pleasing to the eyes and it perfected the fairy tale graphical style. While the graphic is magnificent, the 2D plat-forming gameplay is just average. There are virtually zero depth in puzzles and progression, basically a child can play this game and get to the end without fail. Trine excels in the mega casual plat-forming department, but if you are looking for any form of challenge at all, this is the wrong game to be buying.

reviewText:
This is /one/ of my favourite indie games for three reasons and i'll tell you why:
1. The visuals are stunning, lovingly crafted and still look beautiful three+ years on.
2. The main gameplay point, one where you play one of three characters which you can swap between seamlessly makes for some really cool basic puzzling and combat.
3. The story itself is somewhat generic fantasy but that's something that really appeals to me and pulls this off in a manner that is not too sterotypical to the point where it becomes annoying but is just cliched enough that you recognize and enjoy it.

A great platformer, the high point being it's stunning visuals and rope-swinging thief character.

This is basically Lost Vikings 4. You have three very different characters that all need to get through a side-scrolling platformer. The controls are a little clumsy, and were clearly meant for a game controller.

If you enjoy the pseudo-co-op Lost Vikings style of gameplay, you'll like this. Don't play it with mouse and keyboard. You'll get pretty frustrated.

reviewText:
When asked to describe my thoughts about Trine, only one word comes to mind.
NOPE!

I was shocked, literally shocked when I viewed the review of this game. One after another kept saying it is good.
But it's so far from the truth.
When one delves deeper into the depths of Trine one might not come back the same as he once was.
Trine shares a common trait with certain platformers, for instance you must collect certain items each level to get that perfect score. Yet most levels require several playthroughs before you can finish them 100%, not that it's bad.

But when you come to a certain point where you needed to jump slightly instead of running off of it, and that wasn't the first time you forgot it either, comes frustration. And as I was playing things just kept adding up.

The story was pure horribleness, the attempt at humour was even worse, the wizard is the most annoying character in the game, once the thief is dead you might as well restart the level seeing as most levels requires her to finish.
The items are terrible, I can't remember if I ever found something for the wizard, not that I would care to either but there's a certain principle of things.

The enemies are pure moronic, they will either try to kill you with a wall between you and him. Or just casually walk off a cliff trying to get to you. Bats are only there to rid you of your health, a lazy enemy at best.

This game is stupid, I don't know why nor would I be able to comprehend anyone that likes this.
My joy was killed at the beginning of the game, and the horrors of 2player mode (control-wise) ensured me that I would never be playing this again.

Also, why does this game have or even need 2 sequels, I can think of at least several things that could've benefited from all the money and time that went into their creation. Like planting a tree or stepping on my balls so I would've been midly distracted when hearing such news.

reviewText:
Starts out easy enough and fairly enjoyable.  The puzzles get slightly harder, but its fairly even through out the levels.  Then all of a sudden at the end, the puzzles get much harder, and there are unreasonable amounts of enemies.  They just spawn, and spawn, and spawn, and you have to wait until they are done before you can complete the puzzle.  Then the last level shoots the difficulty all the way up to completely insane.  I was playing medium difficulty, and after getting killed 6 times after spending 5 minutes climbing, I went down to easy mode, which didn't make much difference.  The last level would make a nun curse out loud.

Other than the ridiculous difficulty ramp, the story is bland and tacked on between the levels.  The enemies are all basically the same skeleton, and are plain and boring.  You are always forced to fight them as they will aggressively chase after you, pulling off insane manoeuvres like leaping 40 feet in the air to grab the ledge you are on.

Overall, the game was OK but did not live up to the hype.  Worth buying if you like side-scrollers and it is on sale.
voteText: 6 of 20 people (30%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Remarkably frustrating for such a shallow, simplistic game. Repetitive gameplay, very little challenge unless you go for the extra experience and hidden areas. Oversaturated graphics look pretty cool but can be distracting at times. Nice music. Story is generic and skeletal at best but doesn't waste your time or detract from the gameplay, and the voice acting is pretty good. Occasionally it is difficult to tell the environment apart from the background, and sometimes parts of the level obstruct the camera.\n\nOverall it's not bad; I did play it through to the end. Still, it's nothing too special, even from an indie developer. On a numeric scale I'd rate it a 3/5.

reviewText:
Did I really just write a whole review about what I hated about Trine, copy it to clipboard, and then accidentally lose it copying the lyrics of Supertramp's The Logical Song" into a review for Chantelise?

Yeah. I did.

Anyway
date: this game starts out with the neat idea of a puzzle/adventure game - which seemed to impress a lot of people when it came out - only to stop being creative halfway through and produce a game with the audacity of a day-old gumwad. Stop playing halfway through - I guarantee you did all the enjoyable parts already

reviewText: I feel like people are fooling themselves into liking this game based soley on the beautiful graphics and barely original gameplay. The controls are sloppy and imprecise, which is particularly egregious for a puzzle platformer, the level design is repetitive in all respects except aesthetics, and the balancing of advantages and disadvantages between the three characters is almost non-existent. The game is alright some of the time, but for the most part it just feels like an exercise in futility. It could be a whole lot better if the characters didn't move like they were permanently amped up on cocaine. Seriously why do they have to go so fast? It's the main reason the control feels so poor.\nReally wanted to like it but I seriously don't understand the hype. 3/10

reviewText:
Oh god, Trine is one of the most boring and monotonous games I've ever played. It really doesn't get much more trivial than this for a platformer, even Super Mario Bros. has more variety and little unnecessary filler.

The AI is dumb and will constantly fall off ledges and jump back up, only to fall off again. Weapons are slow and inaccurate, the wizard's conjuration ability requires such precision that it becomes useless in any combat situation. Also, why can't I jump and fire arrows or use my conjuration spells in the air? Stupid limitations.

The premise is interesting, the Trine mechanics are innovative, albeit contrived. The story is lacklustre. The narration during the loading screens is so slow and fragmented that I can't be bothered waiting to hear what's being told.

The levels are all too similar in layout and lack inspiration. The puzzle mechanics aren't challenging and are too predictable, they seem to be the only reason for the physics engine to exist in the first place.

Co-op is almost unplayable and seemed tacked on just because" as both players control one of three characters
date: but only have access to two of the characters at a time
recommended: which slows down gameplay considerably. It also doesn't make sense in context with the Trine itself. The option for three player co-op is there but I'm not certain many people would be able to take advantage of this on PC."

reviewText: This game is gorgeous, and also the core gameplay design is highly effective. You can switch the 3 characters at any given time if you are required to progress further in a level. The puzzles are also interesting. But my problem is that they treat you as if you were a kid. Is this game made for children? I don't think so. But when you play it, you feel like a child. And I mean that in a negative way. Nowadays, such platform and puzzle games are usually serious and hard to complete. But this one... it cannot be taken seriously, no way. And it isn't funny either. It is way too easy to complete, and the storytelling is so childish that you wanna scream. It has a hype surrounding it which I cannot tolerate. Get serious people. This game is a kitsch. I'll try Trine 2, who knows... I still have some spark of interest left. Maybe part 2 will be better.

reviewText:
Having three characters in one was an original and worthy idea. However, in solo, that concept break down because of Zoya. Zoya has a grappling hook, that allows her to bypass most puzzles, and zoom accross levels. It's fun to stay in the air for a long time, but that doesn't provide for interesting challenges. Also, since she is also good in combat, she makes Pontius optional, and since Amadeus is so limited, he too is almost optional.

The game is obviously meant to be played in coop, so that each character's weaknesses must be compensated by the other's strenghts. You wouldn't be able to zoom accross the level with Zoya, because you would have to find way for Pontius and Amadeus to cross the obstacles. However, I haven't had an opportunity to try that, so i can't tell you if that actually works.

However, regardless of whether you liked this game, I do recommend Trine 2, which is awesome in all regards.

reviewText:
I do not really have a longwinded review for this game (like I do for many others). At its core:

+ The graphics are really good and the levels look nice.
+ The music, SFX, and dialog sound pretty good overall.
+ The characters are somewhat funny.
+ The idea/mechanics of the game are interesting, but...

- They are executed poorly, in my opinion. Many others would disagree, but this is the biggest point of the game to me. I got severely bored only after 1 hour of play and I was quite happy to get done with the game. I mean no disrespect to the creators, but it just did not click with me. It was mostly repetitive and stale.

Others would presumably disagree.

reviewText:
Trine is an action/puzzle platformer with 3 types of heroes, 2 types of bosses and 1 type of level.

The graphics are pretty gorgeous, but unfortunately for the gameplay it's not great. There is quite a mess on screen and it's sometimes hard to tell a bonus pickup from an enemy attack.

The controls - which should be the most important thing for a platformers - don't allow for enough precision and feel sloppy, which will often trigger misses. Not that it matters because the game is too easy anyway.

All the levels feel exactly the same, beyond level 1 there is hardly any new mechanics, from there it's just grinding your way through.

The fixed camera placement is annoying. You know objects are there but the camera won't budge or allow you to place objects outside the current field of vision.

There are just 2 bosses, they're not epic, just merely a slightly tougher foe, and they come back several times in later levels.

Not much variety in enemies either, it's just the same skeletons from the beginning to the end.

All in all, this is just like playing the same level 15 times over again, with a different backdrop.

I can appreciate some may be drawn by the medieval fantasy storytelling or by the luxurious backdrops. The graphics got overhauled recently with the enchanted edition and it's quite superb. One can wish the gameplay had got improved instead!

reviewText: Personally, I would wait for this game to go on sale after playing through the entire thing. If you take your time with this game, you will have fun. But there can be points where it gets to be too much and you just want to get to the next level. Once you feel this way, the game becomes a hassle. The sequel is much, much better because it addresses pretty much every issue with the game. Brief review for this, I know, but I can't bring myself to dedicate too much more time to anything related to this garbage game.

Trine is a great game. Lots of fun to play with a friend on your couch. Grafix are awesome, soundtracks matches the style and riddling together how to solve the levels is great.

So why don't recommend the game? We just tried the last level and it has everything to kill all the fun you had before:


You have to jump up a tower under time pressure as lava is rising from the ground. It's hard to not play it alone as you need to switch characters quickly. And an evil guy is conjuring items like boxes and planks right in your face. So three bad things you never got trained in all the levels before. I cannot understand how to do such a bad game design.

It's a real pity, but I cannot recommend the game to anybody who doesn't like hardcore game difficulty changes. :[

reviewText:
This game is terrible

The music and setting is cliched and forgettable, the plot is a joke, the only two bosses are rehashed several times and are almost identical, there's no final boss, every level and challenge is the same, casting shape spells as a wizard is unweildy (you couldn't have just allocated a shape to a unique button?).

Combat is a laugh, mash the trigger button to win, every enemy is the same skeleton (spooky), the game throws an absurd number of enemies at me to complely ignore and jump over.

The checkpoints enable you to cheese the game way to easily, which is kind of necessary since once your warrior dies you're ♥♥♥♥ out of luck.

I could go on forever about how the last two and a half hours I marathoned this game were some of the most miserable, tedious, worthless hours of my life but I'd rather pool my resources into getting past this game and hopefully enjoy the next one.

Go ahead and downvote it you idiots, everyone has ♥♥♥♥ taste except me.

reviewText:
Trine is a beautiul 2D platformer, where players have to make their way through caves, crypts and dungeons to reach their final goal. The story is around a thief, a wizard and a knight who managed to reach a sacred item - the Trine - which then bound their souls together into one single body. Due to this, they have to solve the logic problems in their journey together in order to get past traps they won't be able to solve separately.

The gameplay is really beautiful and reminds to the fairy tales of Grimm. The pretty lighting and water effects help bringing the fabulous atmosphere. The music is pleasant and the voiceovers are also nice.

The story is a fable written as the player progresses in the game. Also the game comes with achievements and controller support. It is really a pleasure playing it, I totally recommend it.

reviewText:
I just beat the game today and decided to review it while it's still fresh in my mind.  This is also my first Steam review, so I hope it's ok.

Anyway, this game takes roughly 10 hours to beat.  After that, you can go back and get achievements if you want.  That would require you mainly to go back through the levels to collect everything (treasure, etc.) you missed the first time around.  I'd imagine that could take roughly another 5-10 hours to do all of that, depending on how well you did completing the levels the first time through.

Good game was good.  If you're into medieval platformers with good graphics, this game may be for you.  You take control of a knight, thief, and wizard.  Each has their own abilities and you can alternate between each character at any time to get through certain parts of the levels.  The knight is mainly good for fighting close range.  The thief fights well from afar with arrows and can use a grappling hook of sorts to grapple and swing to areas.  The wizard is able to conjure blocks, platforms, and bridges to get through the levels...which comes in real handy and lessens frustration that you might get from other platformers since the wizard can just cast a bridge the size of your choosing to cross two platforms without fear of falling and dying.

The music I'd describe as easy listening medieval.

Graphics are colorful and nice.  No complaints.

The only complaint I would have if I had to get nit-picky would be that sometimes your momentum when jumping onto a platform from below may make you lose your footing by making you slide a bit and falling.  I usually used the thief when jumping around so I could just grapple if I fell.

reviewerDisplayName: トップハットのきやき
reviewText:
Trine is one of those little gems that you overlook for the longest time, only to finally give it a whirl and kick yourself repeatedly for waiting. I don't think I've been so gleefully surprised by a single game as I have by this one in a long time, if ever.

The game is a true old fashion puzzle-platformer where the player controls 3 characters; a Wizard who can create platforms and boxes for mana, a Thief who can swing about and attack with a bow, and a Knight who bests his allies at combat. While you only control one at a time, you can switch between the 3 at will using 1-2-3 respectively, and you'll need to do so constantly to overcome the challenges the game throws at you.

If you're a fan of platformers, you should have this game already. If not, get it immediately or at least the next time it's on sale. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText: A simple and succicnt way to describe this game would be Lost VIkings without the hassle of micromanaging each Viking on screen at the same time. But that doesn't do the game justive on just how much -better- that makes a game like this. You still have to manage three seperate health bars, but the ability to on the fly switch and keep the other two members of the Trine safe really makes this whole concept go. Not to mention of course the  abilities of the Trine making the puzzle platforming an enjoyable cerebral exercise that isn't a strain to complete in the simple functionality sense but in the actual solving as a puzzle should be. As impressive as it can be, one doesn't solve a rubix cube with their feet, and one shouldn't play a game with poor mechanics and controls. Trine does not suffer from these issues and infact excels in these departments.

reviewText: Trine is a great coop game. I was able to get a few non-gamers to play it due to the ability to assist your fellow player through any obstacle. Try it, and you'll want to play the sequel immediately.

reviewText:
The Good:
- Beautiful graphics and artwork.
- Some challenging puzzles.
- Very unique and interesting game mechanic with the 3 simulataneous characters to get past the monsters, traps, and various puzzles.
- Rather thin but amusing story with good voice acting.

The Bad:
- Most puzzles are far too easy.
- The boss fights can be either way too easy or ridiculously unfair.
- Combat overall can be a rather glitchy affair. The AI can get stuck, making them easy targets for your thief and her bow. Overall, except for bosses, the enemies pose no real threat compared to falling into a spike pit.
- The physics can get frustrating. Stacking boxes or getting platforms rotated properly can be a pain sometimes.

Final Verdict:
- Certainly worth the couple dollar asking price in a sale. I wouldn't pay full price for this title, but given what it goes for every Steam sale, a real bargain. It also is appealing as something that can be played in short spurts and still be enjoyed, which is about all I have time for these days.

reviewText:
The game is overall a joyride. It has splended graphics, a funny story, and really cool gameplay.

Overall: 9/10



Graphics: 10/10
It has superb graphics, especially for a platformer. Every nook and cranny of every part of every level was a sight to see.

Story: 8/10
Its story was really neat. It's silly and all, but still fun to watch and learn about.

Gameplay: 8/10
Most of its gameplay mechanics were absolutely fun. Anything and everything had physics, which made combat really fun. The biggest flaw of its gameplay was the SOMETIMES horrendous spawning. There were several times where I died, waited a few seconds, and respawned only to instantly die again (I played on the hardest difficulty). Other than that, the gameplay was incredibly fun.

reviewText:
Pros:

+Awesome developer (Frozenbyte)
+Great narration & storytelling
+Local & (with the new free upgrade Enchanted Edition) online co-op
+Amazing graphics & visuals (especially with Enchanted Edition)
+Very good soundtrack
+Good gameplay (I recommend a controller)
+Nice level designs that can be challenging
+Intriguing mix of playable characters & abilities
+Excellent attention to detail
+Progresses & plays almost like a children's storybook (a pro, in my opinion)
+Encourages exploration w/hidden items

Cons:

-Can occasionally feel repetitive & monotonous
-It would be nice if the playable characters could grasp ledges & edges like it seems most enemies can

Highly recommended! While there's a bit of room for improvement (that's where Trine 2 comes in), Trine has aged very well and has now been made even better with the new upgraded Enchanted Edition that adds local and online co-op, refreshed graphics and visuals, and a few other enhancements.

If only every game developer cared about their fans and customers as much as Frozenbyte, we'd have a much better gaming community and industry.
